element_texts.text:
Lucy 
May 13 1835                                                                                                                                        Bangor May 13 1835
Dear Lucy
I have been naughty not to write to you before, since Isaac & Nettie came, but I know Isaac wrote last week, so I thought you would not care so much.  It seems so odd to have them at Eliab's instead of here, but we have seen them about every day so far.  What a splendid specimen of health and manliness little Mayo is! I wish I could learn Percie not to be such a clinger to "Mamma".  He is never really happy but a few moments at a time, even out doors, unless "Mamma" will  "drop floor" with him and keep by his side. To get down anywhere at any time, on the floor in the house, or on the ground, is "drop floor."  It seems as if he could not be weaned from me.  When out doors with Lizzie
[left-hand side] Mary notice next letter

and Mayo, if I am not there too, he must come in every few minutes and stand & look at me a little & then out again.  If I am out of sight a moment, when he is ever so busy at play, it is "Mamma away," Mamma away, away away".  Lizzie's being here will be a capital thing for her.  I turn him over to her care a good deal & he is learning to love her very much.
15- When I had got so far, I saw Nellie & Mayo came, Nettie says she wrote a long letter to you wherein she said everything, so that I need not write at present, but as I had begun, thought I might as well finish - I have not been very well for a little past  - distress through my chest, right side, back & shoulder blade - much increased by swallowing.  Sabbath it grew more painful & Dr Mc. came in the evening - said he had

many such cases this spring. Slight inflammation of pleura and lungs. I felt sabbath day exactly as when sick at Hampden.  He left me medicine, recommended hot foot baths, mustard poultice on the side & cochella powder the second day.  I feel almost well today - think some of going shopping & taking my physic after I come back.  Lizzie is out on the sidewalk with Percie.  I am going to see about a bonnet for Almeda & getting Lizzie's fixed over etc. Mallie has had a fresh installment of ornaments from Easthampton - as many more minerals, shells, images and pretty things as she had before.  Nettiie says - I have not seen them - Her bonnet & Gertie's hat are coming from N.York City - Hattie has got also a coral necklace ( & armulets to match) with a gold clasp & little locket, marked "G.E.M." for Gertie.  We think such arrangements are

wasted powder, but please don't say anything when you write.  It will do no good, only trouble the feelings.  I am anxious to hear if the rose arrived safely and is likely to live, if not there are plenty more here, if I can ever get a chance to send them.
P.M Nettie, Mallie & self went shopping as proposed -  accomplished a fine parcel of business - spoke for Almeda's bonnet.  Nettie is up here this afternoon  - Isaac setting out currant bushes, Mayo & Percie running about in the yard.  Lizzie gone up to the grove with Lizzie Page, Ellen down town.  I thank you much for the root - Am using it faithfully - In much haste with great care.   Aff.- Daught. Lucy

Mr Beacroft died a few days since, little less than a year since his wife died - I will try to send you an obit.

Lucy May 22nd 55
                                                                                                                                                 Bangor - May 22 - 1855

Dear Mother
I am afraid you think I have been rather remiss about writing lately, but there has not seemed to be anything to write.  Isaac and I have been gardening more or less every day - By his kind assistance, my posey garden shines unwontedly.  I like ever so much comfort working out there & I believe grow strong daily.  Percie is out as much as half the time when it is pleasant, -  his cheecks are growing delightfully hard and rosey as well as his skin getting to be a fine brown - he tans very easy.  He is taking to Lizzie finally, though nobody is quite equal to Mamma yet. Lizzie is more womanly than when here before, & of course two years ought to make some difference
[left-hand side and top] send my special requests as apologies through Mr. Sargent's people, to Alice because what I gave her for a lily was only a tulip.  I thought they were lilacs while all the while they were not out of the ground.  Don't fail to mention it for I know she'll think strange. In haste. good bye- most night.? Lovingly daughter Lucy.

Mayo has been really sick with cold and cankered mouth (as Percie was last winter only worse for about a week, it is getting better now.  Gertie is a little mite of a thing - only think - nine months old in a day or two,  wears long white dresses, & does not begin to sit alone yet.  She seems smart to jump & fly round in one's lap, but she has great delicacy of organization - so very narrow across the shoulders.  Maria is not very smart, had a great many spring feelings, tho' she keeps sound, & would'nt like to have me say she was not well as anybody, so you must not say anything when you write.  She don't like to have anything said because I tell her I know her present feelings are owing to impudence last fall.  She and Nellie have gone, I suppose, to

hear Mrs Johnson lecture to ladies on health this afternoon - this is her second course of seven lectures, said to be worth everybody's hearing.  We have got a beautiful silk bonnet making for Almeda.  I have covered the lounge self alone today I am slightly weary.  Am very much better than when you went away.  After you went away I devoted myself to doing nothing, only to read or write when I felt like it & occasionally to do a little work, for two or three weeks.  Whether this benefited me or whether being out doors a good deal, or taking considerable currant wine, or the mucilage of the root you sent, I know not - perhaps all combined.  By the way, Isaac said I must prepare & lathe the root while green without fail, so I fixed all of it - equal to some hundred dozen whites

of eggs!  Just a quart of wine with it to keep it, and labored daily upon it with extreme dilligence, (so thick it poured like whites of eggs, and consequently not particularly agreeable,) but some of it spoiled before I could use it all - if I had dried the root & used it as I wanted it, it would have been better.  Letters from Minnesota yesterday bring tidings of an infant daughter born to Bill Watson the 9 - of May.  Theodore has 100 acres under plough this spring.  You ask what preparation you can make to go to Elyria - I don't see as anything but to stand ready, at least till you got as far as here.  We want you here these days badly - As for all of us coming to Milo together; I don't think it best to crush, overwhelm & annihilate you all at once.  We have got a new "Prairie rose", honeysuckle (only not a very handsome kind) lily of the valley this spring, besides new fruit & forest trees, I wish you would please to

Lucy  May 1855
Dear Mother
As Nettie says  "I fully intended", and have done so almost every mail since they came from Milo, yet I believe you have not had so many letters as usual from me - When there are so many of us here, there is more going on- particularly shopping, particularly now, Nettie had a good many things to get, & our spring fixings, though we have not done much at fixing this year.  I am very well for me & growing "weller".  Samuel has not been quite well for a few days - I feel almost as if Isaac ought not to go west without you going to Elyria, yet I am afraid to have you go to stay through the hot weather.  The Dr. & Anna seem determined not to give in use but that I am going, but I cannot feel

that it would be quite right this year on account of expenses besides Samuel wants to go as much as I, & to Minn. too, and I think I had better wait & go with him.  Then if he should be sick and I away - I am sorry - because in regard to dress, health & everything, I am well situated to go this year.  In regard to yourself, I do not know what is best, I am sure - it is for you to decide whether to go immediately with Isaac or wait and go in the fall - he will be going then I suppose.  The fish matter will be speedily attended to, I cannot contrive any way for us all to go to Milo together without making much additional expense, as I dare not go by stage, besides the fatiguing considerations for you & Albina with so many people & babies, Eliab & Maria have better go cosily together in a chaise when they get ready, & if we can, the last of summer, Sam'l & I will go.  In haste, with much love to all.
Lucy




that it would be quite right this year on account of expenses besides Samuel wants to go as much as I  to ((unclear)) too, and I think I had better wait & go with him.  Then if he should be sick and I ((unclear.))
I am sorry - because in regard to  orders, health & everything, I am well ((unclear)) to go this year.  In regard to yourself, I do not know what is best, I am sure - it is for you to decide whether to go immediately with Isaac or wait and go in the fall - he will be going then I suppose.  The fish matter will be specially attended to, I cannot contribute any way for us all to go to Milo together without making much  additional expense, as I dare not go by stage, besides the fatiguing considerations for you & ((unclear)) with us may perplex babies Eliah & Marcia how better go cosily together in a chaise when they get ready, if we can, the last of Summer, Samuel & I will go.  In haste with much love to all.
Lucy

Lucy Furber June 23 1855                                                                                                   Bangor June 23rd 1855
Dear Mother
I imagine you will feel somewhat anxious before Monday night to hear of our welfare, but there seems to be no way of sending before that time.  Eliab will write Monday, I presume, and tell you what a comfortable ride we had had home - I never was on the road when it was so bad, - partly in consequence of heavy teams passing since the rain, and partly because of repairing when the ground was so wet.  We got here safe, but very tired.  Percie seemed to think that nobody but me, not even his father could do anything for him, but he soon got over it, for I was obliged to go to bed.  He seemed delighted to get home, and after a little time went to play with Lizzie and was very good all the afternoon.  He seemed 
[left-hand side] quite "ructious" when he first wakened, but feels nicely now - do write much & often Lucy. Will put in the silk now & send the braid with the bundle soon.

weak and does this morning - tips over easily.  Was rather restless last night, started in his sleep often, but I laid it to getting so tired.  He has been out in the piazza this morning and is playing about as usual.  I feel well this morning, what the exception of being sleepy, tired, lame, and back achy!  Was it not fortunate that we had the forenoon instead of the afternoon to come home, in?  We found a letter here for Nettie - wanted to read it, but thought she might like to do so first.  Only Mrs Harlow, Mrs. Martin & Mrs. Blood have been in this morning - all of errands.  There are fifteen fully blown peonies under the winder.  The balsams were in fine order when they got here.  Our visit at Milo does not seem to be very satisfactory to look back upon.  Fatigue, anxiety & sickness on our part, and loss of sleep, disturbance

and anxiety for all of you.  I am sad to think of you Mother, with your cold from Percie's is keeping you uncovered, & then so tired and without sleep all night.  I hope you all went to bed after we came away - particularly Mother and Albina.  Percie had no trouble with his diarrhea on the way down, and so little now, that unless it increases, I shall not think best to check it.  I feel nicely to think we are likely to get along without a doctor.  We will see to the things and try to send them up the fist of the week - I got a letter from Samuel on the way home - the driver had it in his hat & thought best not to keep me waiting!  Ellen & Lizzie were pretty glad to see us - If jars cannot be obtained there, had I better send any.  Please ask Almeda if she would like a butter jar sent?

Do please write to us very often, or we shall be homesick. Mrs. Harlow says Percie's illness was occasioned simply by unusual excitement - says she always noticed he had an unusually large head & such children were always liable to fits if fatigued or excited - when riding, should never be urged to look at things etc. His teeth do not look near so much swollen as when we went to Mother's.Nettie, the lemon shrub slip is all dead,notwithstanding it was heartless. Things in general have grown too, drefully the past week.
Quarter past three, P.M.  Percie has just gone to sleep. Has seemed very nervous & irritable all day & latterly so tired that he would fall down every few steps. but I could continue no way to keep him still long enough to get asleep till just now. You see I save them cents by using this envelope. I guess P. will be nicely after his nap. Slept half an hour

Lucy July 14 '55

                                                                                                                                                  Bangor July 14 - 1855.

I have been so impressed with the idea of the danger of my dear Mother "growing mischievous in her old age," for lack of occupation that I cannot forbear sitting down at once to furnish her, at least, with the innocent employment of reading a letter. Really. Mother, what didos do you contemplate cutting up,and upon whom are your first pranks to be played?  But seriously, I should not imagine that you had lacked for employment either for mind or body for the past few wees. I have thought of you often, with so many little ones, notwithstanding there were several of you, that you would have your hands full. The people arrived about four o'clock- Mallie did not come in. I am so much, much obliged for the many nice strawberries
[left-hand side] see a young crane - Do please write often- I expect Ellen and her people will go t Minn. very soon before fall and what shall I do for so good a girl? good bye Lucy.

only I could'nt help worrying all the while of eating them about your poor bended backs in the heat and among the flies. O, they were so nice. I picked a nice boquet of the last roses of summer and sent don to Mallie tonight, with such other flowers as the garden afford. O, Mother I wish you could see our garden - it never looked half so well before. In my department there is hardly a weed, big or little to be found. I do "dig about and dung" things unweariedly and they reward me for my pains. We have got a gutter put up by the shed, the ground enriched, and tonight Samuel and I put out the grape vines. There were seven or eight fine sprouts. My " queen of the prairie" that I tho't so much of, proves to be a "Baltimore Belle" - a very delicate and handsome rose, but not so high a runner nor so rich a rose as the other.

My damask rose that came from Milo is as dark as ever. I think if you put a plenty of charcoal round the roots, you will see them darker another year. I went down into Mr. Orff's garden a day or two since. They have some superbly handsome flowers, particularly roses - a "Prince Albert," which is very beautiful - Mrs. Harlow has a "Paul Joseph" rose in bloom, which is the handsomest thing in the shape of a flower that I ever saw, I think. The queer names amuse me, as doubtless they will you. Mrs. Harlow bends her back in her garden about the whole of every forenoon, rain or shine, unless it rains or shines very powerfully. Mary is away & Sarah helps not much. There is considerable said about Mr. Leo's lectures - an agent for the Am. For. and Chris. Union - I think I wrote to you about him - he is said to be an unusually fine speaker - I have not

heard him. The Catholics dislike him much. I think people must have been "pretty good stuff" to "go to the fourth of July and stay from eight till four. Were they alive next day?
Mond morn - July 16 - I did hear Mr. Leo yesterday and must say I have not heard so eloquent a speaker for a long time - he seems to be a very good man too. the Catholics are quite excited about him - some go to hear him, Ellen started one night, but met some of her Irish friends who told her all manner of falsities about him & persuaded her that he was a monster of wickedness so she turned about again. I ought to answer Nettie's letter, but can't very well today - Tell her that I saw mentioned in his last to us that if he went to Minn. as he intended, he should not be back for a month - Percie is so much better that I guess if it is best to give him the beech leaf tea now. His chalk mixture with cinnamon helped him speedily. Don't trouble your mind about the waist Nettie is fitting - I did it very easily indeed from an old one, though I never could fit a new waist. How I should like to

Lucy July 26 1855
Bangor July 26 - 1855
Dear Mother
We have been expecting a letter from some of you for some days but I believe I will not wait for it any longer. Ellen Brown came here yester P.M. She did intend to go to Bucksport last night, but the stage left her, so she waited till this morning. She said you had returned to Milo> I can't really tell how long you were at Brownville, but it seems to me not as long as I expected. We are just through Commencement - It came a month earlier then usual so as to give the students who wish it, time to teach. Rev. Harry White, Rev. Mr. Perry from Blanchard and Rev. Ariel Perkins from Philipston, Mass., were sent here to bed and board. Mr. Perkins did not know who I was till in conversation he discovered that Royalston

was my native place, then inquired my name & seemed ever so glad to see me, though we know nothing at all of each other - He is a great brown-faced, hard brearthed, sort o'lazy acting man, but improved upon acquaintance - Unusually interesting in family prayer, reminded me of Dr. DeWitt. Seemed to understand to the bottom every subject we touched upon. He happened to be at Orono visiting his wife's friends & so came down with them to Commencement. His wife died last fall - he has one little boy of two years, now at his father's.
Lizzie said Albina wanted to keep those knives, but you know it would spoil my set - and I had rather keep them. If she wants some, I can get them for her, but you know her keeping those would leave me four odd ones.
Mr. J. P. Thompson's lecture before the Rhetorical Society Thursday evening, was the most perfectly good that I have heard for long - His subject

The Comparitive value to mankind of civilization and Christianity. You know he is pastor of the Tabernacle Church and one of the editors of the Independent. A plain common sense man with a great live heart, living in the world and having an intimate knowledge of everything that is going on in all countries, and a broad deep sympathy with mankind and an interest in all the great movements of the day. It does stir one up so to hear such a man once in a while - plain spoken and simply dressed - a black cravat & brown coat, (dispensing with clerical black) and altogether eschewing the "churning of words." Mallie & Gertie are doing finely - Gertie was sick a few days. I expect to have Mary's cousin, quite of an unmentionable age, when Ellen goes away. If you have stocking yarn for Ellen, please send it soon, as she may go in two or three weeks, but don't trouble about it, as she can buy here.

I had a nice letter from Isaac a few days since, but none from Anna for a long time. It seems as if I had many things to say, but Lizzie is not very well today & Nancy Baying is here talking to her - 'tis about dinner time too. Percie always tells his name P.P. Furber. He loves Father & Mother Bangor full and "folks in general" five pecks. He will play with a handful of flowers, pulling off the leaves and placing them in various heaps and positions, two hours at a time without hardly speaking at all. Sam'l has come. good bye-

                                                                                                                                             daughter Lucy.

Bangor Aug. 16 - 1855.

Dear People, all

                        Hastily, as usual, I snatch a few moments to write to you. I feel so confused and hurried that I hardly know where to begin.
                       First, you know Mr. & Mrs. Packard are here. Just as good as can be, all one brother and sister (Mr.P. reminds one continually of Joseph) get sort of company, you know. Then one day last week Mr. Temple called and of course I must invite him & his spouse to tea, which I did for Tues. evening last, and thinking to follow Madam Harlow's good example & save cake, I invited also Messrs. Emmett & Wells with their wives, which I have long intended  to do - just after they were invited, (though Mrs. Emmett was at Milo & could not come) Mr. Temple came in to the store saying he should not be able to come till Thursday, so nobody was benefited by all my labors in the way of custard jelly cake etc. but Mr. & Mrs. Wells - however, we enjoyed their visit much & have got to have it over again for Mr. Temple. Mr. S. coaxed us into buying his father's Memories - very excellent I presume, still we should not have got the book just now without an invitation - the

good man's countenance is worth the price of the book almost - Well, all this fussing, together with "sights" of callers and Mr. & Mrs. Packard, while I am longing to be with Maria all the time, though I hope the worst is over. She was quite sick two or three days with dysentery, occasioned chiefly by excitement talking with Mary, who is slightly apt to "get odd", Gertie has been ailing all along - and Monday was taken worse - tuesday was in a stupid state all day - at might they were much alarmed & feared congestion of the brain, but I think it was weakness & exhaustion - & that the long sleep of lethargy was the crisis. I want down early Wednes. morn, staid all the forenoon found her looking better than I expected, though very sick. While I was there, she had a long sweet sleep, with closed eyes, her flesh grew warmer & her skin moist and she continues to improve. If her diarrhea does not return, I think she will get over it. She is very poor, most as bad as Percie was last summer. She is a little frail thing - takes cold so easily. They were going to telegraph to Hattie, but concluded not to - she is coming this fall. I guess Mary knows how much it troubled Maria - she is as good as possible now, but I don't know as I could get along with such a creature in the house. Ellen is so good. The

more company I have & the more there is to do, the garden she grows - but the, she can't well help it, when I am always good and pleasant to her, & I talk with her & let her keep me calculate just enough to please her. I am sad to think of her going away. Well, I am not through yet - Yesterday immediately after I returned from Eliab's (according to intimation had two days before ) a hack stopped at the door, and there from emerged two of Samuel's cousins from Newton Mass. James and Mary Sykes - he 22 years old - a smart, fashionable sprig - book-keeper at Newcomb's, corn and flower dealer, State St. Boston, she a very pretty girl of seventeen with a round smiling face, pretty brown hair, with an abundance of natural ringlets, all over her head and shoulders. They are very easy & at home, so we get on nicely- don't know how long they will stay- suppose three or four days. I thought we were to have no company this summer. As you may suppose, I don't do much but keep things straight. This P.M. is appointed to go on a ride to Old Town - I don't know whether I shall go myself or resign in favor of Lizzie, and take the time to recruit myself. Lizzie was not very well for a few days,but at Mrs. Packard's instigation, I cured her with raspberry leaf tea. Mr. & Mrs.P. are both in feeble health. Mr. P.

suffers constantly with pain in his side - liver complaint. He has not been with his people since last Apr. and grows worse instead of better, particularly for the past few days.If he is not better soon, he will not be able to finish his engagement here for Prof. Shepard. I think they both feel rather blue at times. He is a very smart man. He lets me read his sermons -everybody says so. She has had a very sad life -full of trials and deep afflictions; loss of friends and everything, almost. O, how many flowers I do have -wish I could supply you all. Wish you could see the spreadiness & sprawlation of my scarlet verbena. Fuschia all in bloom in the garden - a very handsome variety red, with a rich purple middle. I don't find much time to admire them just now. "Jack in the Hibiscus bush" of Isaacian memory looks finely. Mrs. P. calls it "Jack in a puzzle." Dear Mother your long desired child's papers shall be attended to if I can possibly compass it. E. is away from the store considerable & Sam'l, if such a thing is possible, busier than ever, first at Searsport, then Oldtown, then Stillwater, besides attending to the store; has loaded one vessel with lumber to go to Fayal and is now loading another for Malaga - means to try to get rid of it. Well, my  time is more than out - do write often - had a letter from Almeda last night - goodbye, lovingly Lucy

Bangor Aug 17th 1855

Folks at Milo

                      I send I gave to day by Mr. Bradeen a letter from Bangor  via Ill.,  Minnessota, & Bangor at our house all well as usual, Lucy, very tired as usual when we have company

Cousin Ja's Sykes & Sister are here for a few days from Newton, Mass. Mr. Packard's health needs doctoring we all went to Old Town yesterday Mallie & Gertie are both yet sick, her head was supposed to be effected is now apparently better, Mallie has not been well for 2 or 3 weeks, some of the time quite sick, dysentery and excitement, hope she will improve as Gertie gets better.

 In a hurry S.W. Furber

I want Isaac to look at Uncle Marks colt and see what it is worth

Lucy Aug. 30 ' 55

                                                                                                                               Bangor Aug. 30 - 1855.

Dear Mother & all the people

                        It is three o'clock P.M. I thought this morning that I would sit right down and sew all day, but I went into the garden to pick some corn to send to Eliab's by Lizzie, and somehow I did not get in again till ten o'clock. What with trimming tomato vines, tying up thing that the wind had blown down, gathering divers sorts of seeds, picking a boquet & watering plants, I was busy fussing all the while, with a little happy chattering body at my side. Well when I got in, there were my seeds to do up & label, pepper grass seed to rub out & winnow, nasturtiums to pickle (pickled yester & day before - when those were fixed, I remembered) that my tumblers of jelly had not been tied up, so the papers must  be cut & that attended to, then the wind

[left-hand side and top] eat green stuff, & he very little - sweet corn is large enough now. Dea. Addams died suddenly of heart disease Tuesday night walked up to the seminary in the afternoon- Eighty-two years old - never had a sick day I think he said. Percie wakes me most every morning by climbing over into bed, saying "How do Mover " &"How do faver," Sam'l has gone to Searsport  to be gone till tomorrow night. Please do write soon & often. to Lucy. Are your plants flourishing? Mine are, apparently.

was blowing the crab apples all off the tree, so I sent Ellen to pick them & I went to work & preserved them. Last of all Percie's sun bonnet was starched & getting too dry, so it as necessary for one to iron that, as Ellen never does such things. Now I am seated & washed & combed & dressed, ready to finish out the day writing, without perhaps touching my sewing; which, by the way, is getting sadly behind these few weeks since I have had so many other things to attend to. Day before yesterday I picked about 3/4 of the nasturtiums - (had a ten quart pan full in all - want to send you a bottle). Yesterday I finished picking those, cut all the sage - another pan full - picked beans & corn for dinner, nipped off every end of all the squash vines to keep them within bounds & let the first ripen cut all the squash & turnip leaves which shaded the squashes too much, picked rhubarb

for sauce, put out my small tulip bulbs, broke the handle of my trowel digging in the "dirt of the ert," and rode down to Maria's when Sam'l went from dinner - we took Percie & S. carries him to the store I kept him till after 5 o'clock, good as a puss. Lizzie stayed at Maria's lately - she has a real hard time - was sick abed two days - Mond. & Tues. Dr. Payne said she had a fever, that yesterday she was up all day tending baby, sewing etc. Sammie has been unable to be at the store all the week - an attack of dysentery - they had the doctor for him yesterday - he has had it slightly for several weeks. Gertie is better --hungry as Percie was last fall. Monday morning, when Maria found she could not get up, Eliab telegraphed for Hattie - they expect her this week. I shall feel greatly relieved when she comes.

                Just after you started Friday, old

Mrs. Wingate came in to spend the day, somewhat to my discomfort, though being a sort of Aunt to Samuel, I must not say nothin'. She is seventy two yrs old, & as you are aware, fat. However, I took nice care of her all day - she slept two hours dilligently, and loud, on my bed. About five o'clock, to my surprise & consternation, Mr. & Mrs. Temple made their appearance, after all the custards were eaten up you know! Mr. P. & wife went to Mrs. Blood's to tea. Howsomedever we got on splendidly. Mrs. T. is homely & clever - rather interesting. Sabbath forenoon Mr. Packard preached a good sermon on foreknowlege.  In the afternoon I borrowed it & wrote it off, leaving him none the wiser. Tues. morn, they went away: Mr. P's side feels much better but the pain has gone more to his chest - he sweats very much in the night. I don't think his symptoms very encouraging.  Did you have any frost Mon. night - we covered every thing we could & in the morning the sidewalk was white, but nothing injured in the garden.Our tomatoes are turning red - they are monstrous big. How many shelled beans I can we do devour. It is too bad that they can't eat more of it at Eliab's. None but he dare

Lucy Sept. 13 55
Dear Mother

   James & Lizzie did not go this morning as I supposed they would when I wrote a few hasty words last night. Now it is half past 9- Sam'l has just come & brought no letter from you all, wherat we are some disappointed, wanting much to hear from you. The sad operation is all over & Mr. Rider is nicely comfortable. Feels better than either time before. Sam'l and Eliab both went to the Dr.'s with him. Eliab saw the whole operation, so did James - Sam'l went into another room - he is easily overcome at such a time. The doctor was two minutes with his knives , & ten before it was all done up. Gertie seems - well, & was going to say a little better, but can only say she is certainly no worse, and the Dr. says that is enough to encourage us a good deal she was so very low yesterday. He is giving cod liver oil -the only thing he knew of that could help her, as she is so low he does not give her any active medicine. They rub her also in  the oil, as he says she may be much strengthened in that way. We just about gave her up yesterday. I never saw so pitiful looking a child. I wrote to Anna today, letting the news. We feel so relieved now Mr. R. is through - stays in his chamber - Maria is not going to see him at all - she is so worn down, we think it might trouble her too much. He does not look near as badly as before - good night

great loves to Nettie & all                                                                                  Lucy.
Do be careful of all you dear selves, particularly the Mother of us all.

Lucy Sept. 15, 1855

                                                                                                                                                         Bangor Sept. 15 -1855.

Dear Mother & people

                                   Your letter came to hand this evening. I have just finished reading it. Will, with alacrity, obtain and forward the articles desired as soon as I can, but when that will be, I am unaware. You will please bear in mind that we have no house, that I have no Lizzie to assist in the care of Percie, that Maria is and is likely to be disabled from duty for a long time to come, that our house is at present considered a hospital & that my bones are often weary., - but in process of time we will hope to accomplish whatever is desired. In regard to making the dress, nothing would give me greater pleasure, - saving & excepting, it might be, to make similar articles for a pair of twins for myself-! than to fit out divers

[left-hand side] Hope Isaac won't quite lose himself in his glad glee these days. Am glad for your Joy.

beautiful & twinly garments for the darlings that I want so much to see, but as it is, am afraid that I cannot consistently do it. If it is best can undoubtedly  - get Ann Page to do some sewing- she is very nice, you know. I wrote two bits of letters and sent by Lizzie, with some little shirts, a kerchief of which you have left here, and Albina's two dresses, which I sent once before & Mallie brought back. It seems she forgot to hand them to you. We are having queer times now-a-days. I have hardly had any time to sew since Commencement - Mallie feels dreadfully to be here just now, but we all get along famously. Ellen is a perfect treasure, interested for everybody & willing to help everybody. Maria's girl is going to be married soon & is awful ructious & cross. - so she & I have for to hunt up new girls very soon. It is wonderful how comfortably Mr. R. gets along - had had scarcely any pain & slept well every night. He does

not look nor feel near so bad as last fall. Gertie, we hope is a little better - she is very troublesome. I do think more & more of Dr. McRuen - he dies not seem to glory a bit. I like much his feelings in regard to performing surgical operations. It did not seem to me that Gertie could live through another day, without help, when she came up here Wednes. morning. 

16 - Sabbath day . It came ten o'clock last night & I left writing, but fearing you will be troubled if you do not get a letter by tomorrow's mail, I'll finish it today. The d/rs. McRuen Field have just left - have taken the pins from Mr. R's face & expressed much delight at the appearance thereof. He thinks Gertie is improving a little, but says she is by no means out of danger. She moans & teases for food almost continually, & still continues to emaciate, which is the most unfavorable symptom - there are others favorable. She has to

be carried about almost all the time. I never ? so poor a child. For the yarn we are very thankful, bit afraid it was too hard for you to spin it. Maria took what was sent. If any more is spun for Ellen by Mrs. Sargent or otherwise, if some of you or Mrs. S are coloring with bark, please dip it in. She would prefer hers colored. She is so goo I would like to gratify her if consistent, but of course make yourselves no trouble. I sent the first & all the tomatoes that have yet appeared on our vines - did not think in season, & we should have got more from down street. Gertie was getting along fairly as they thought (though she kept having ups & downs) till a week ago today. Eliab took her to the table at dinner & with her little quick fingers, she stole a kernel of corn from his late & before they could get it, it was down her throat. She immediately began to grow worse, whether from that course or some other, (the sudden change in the weather) they

Dear Mother

It is past nine & I write in great haste a few words. Lizzie can tell you more than I can write, I will only say that Eliab, Mallie and Hattie are here with poor little Gertie. They came this morning because the air is so much better here than there. They just sent for Dr. McRuen this morning - they felt as if she could not live much longer without some change. She is very low indeed - much sicker than Percie was, and so weak! You know she has not the strength to begin with that he had. The Dr. gives no encouragement. He said he knew of but one thing that could help her, & he had little hope of that - cod liver oil - she was too far gone for chalk mixture. You can't think what a miserable looking little thing she is. How joy & sorrow goes together in this world. Many congratulations to Isaac & Nettie for their

lat acquisitions. I should hardly think Isaac's skin would hold him any way. I want to look at all of them particularly Muffin and Huffin. Waht will they name them. And what will they do with them? Samuel has just come - he is tired - it is late & I must stop, don't know what we shall do without Lizzie. Do write when you can snatch time. I shall so want to hear everything- good night all - do be careful of yourself and yourselves,

                                                                                                                                             Aff. Lucy.

invite Persia? by all means to come here- we can get along some way - I should always be sorry if I did not.

Lucy

  Sept. 18 1855
                                                                                                          Bangor Sept. 18. 1855.

Dear Mother

   By rare good luck, I had an opportunity to go down town yesterday P.M. so I made haste & got some or all of the articles Nettie wished to send with the tommy toes etc. The cambric for slip I will keep here and if you say so, will get Ann Page to make it. I can cut it out & fix the points, so that it will be properly done. The blue dresses I would have kept, hoping bye & bye I might find time to make them, only I did not know the size etc. The calico Maria told me was got at Stone's, I easily found it, but he asked ,8 for the drab. instead of ,6 as you wrote.

Calico, 1 1/2    19
"            "          12
Cambric, 1 3/4 yds 53
4 yds delaine, 47. - 1.88
saddler's silk   24      $2.96
Mayo dress  2 yd 5/6 per yd      1.84    
4.80

The other things Samuel is to attend to today. A carpenter is here today making a dove chamber. The birdies are expected by express tomorrow. Eliab & Mallie were sadly frightened and troubled about Gertie yesterday, but when the Dr. came in the evening, he said he could see no change in her - went up stairs again to examine her & comfort Mallie when just ready to go out - said he should not be surprised any morning to hear that she was dead, she was so very feeble, that any sudden change would not be surprising, but that he thought her no worse, & from her keeping along without sinking lower, he had hope that she would recover. This morning she seemed a little brighter & we all feel easier about her, though only Mallie & Eliab were alarmed yesterday. Very sick children will look differently at different times you

know. When he came in, we told him that they feared she was worse & he went up stairs with some anxiety on his face, so Mallie was confirmed in her opinion that she was worse by the Dr's long face. I told him how she felt - he laughed a little & said he wished people would attend to what he said & not to the way his face looked, as he tried to tell just what he thought. She cannot bear the oil - her bowels are so weak, so they rub in just as much as they can on her back & bowels. The Dr. says that will give her a little strength. She cannot have milk & takes chiefly barley broth.  Dr. Mc. says she must have milk - nothing else so good for a child - but every time she takes it it seems to hurt her. Mr. Rider is doing wonderfully well - his face is almost healed. Dr. is quite delighted about it. Don't you believe I want to go to Milo now as much as ever

I did in my life? Well I must be done & send this down by Mr. Martin to go with the other things. I am going to get a little cap for Percie (hats seem to be going by) shall I get one like it for Mayo? How does the poor little fellow feel nowadays? You don't say a word about him. Don't he feel as if his chance is about gone? I want to see the rogue. Eliab found out Sunday that Mary (the girl) had been drawing some brandy, Madeira, & currant wine bottles, which very likely occasioned her cross spells - he sent her off, bag & baggage, without waiting for Monday! They have shut up house, till baby is well enough to go back & they get another girl. - Goodbye

                                                                                                                    Aff - Lute

Dear People

                   I suppose you will ask Almeda all sorts of questions about every thing & she will answer them in full, so there is little need for me to write, only to tell Nettie about the dress for Mayo.  We think it is darling pretty. If you want another dress of it, please let me know soon, as it may be gone. It is 5/6 per yd. I did not quite know how much to get, but thought two yds for dress & drawers would be right. I have got enough thibet like Percie's last winter best dress for her for ? drawers, & mean to get along with the two dresses. I am making some plain unbleached cotton flannel drawers to put on under his white ones till 'tis time to put on woolen ones. Almeda will tell you what a hurly burly we hospital keepers are in here nowadays- but 'tis all nothing

[upside down at top] When is Mother going to Elyria and who is going with her?

eatables sent by Wednes. Samuel was up river & down river a good deal last week - has four or five people (two corn farmers) to see next tuesday, about logs & lumber - hates to terribly, but says there is no other way. Shall we not be glad when the lumber is fairly out of the way, if it sweeps away six times all our property, as  very likely it may. I won't grumble a word. I wonder how with so many vexations & cares & losses all the time, Samuel can always be the same kind, considerate, good natured man - never speaking a hasty word, nor forgetting to be kind to us all. "Icus", won't you make calculations to stop here & have the babies christened? or would the Dunbarton grandparents be grieved? 'Ts a pity you had not written one mail sooner, then tall the things could have gone up so nicely with the children. You can't think how good it seems about Mr. Rider. His

face will not be disfigured more so much as I feared.Dr. Mc. told Almeda she might be quite proud of his looks by and by! He said there was real pleasure to a surgeon in performing an operation so far as professional feeling was concerned - a consciousness of skill & ability to do it properly & well, & that this consciousness of knowing just what one was doing & wanting to do, gave the requisite nerve to go through with it, but as for their being any pleasure in the cutting, as some said, no, no, no, with much emphasis. He said he could perform an operation on an adult without distress to himself, but he want to such a work on a child as he would go to a whipping post - with shrinking & real distress. The other day in asking a blessing Samuel said kingdom, as soon as he got through, Percie said to me, "Faver said kingdom & didn't say power". Yesterday I was saying to him - he wanted

kitty to sing - I told him she could'nt he said "kitty aint big enough." He often calls me "Mrs. Furber". Last night I put him in his crib just at dark, & had not hear a lisp of noise from him & in a little more than an hour went in to see if he was covered up. As soon as I opened the door, he exclaimed in great glee "Perthy on papa & Mamma's bed" - And there he was, had tumbled all over the bed in the darkness & was curled down, cold as a frog, on the backside with the kitten, I did not know she was in there & thought he asleep all the while. He was just as full of tickle as he could hold, his round eyes shining with roguery. I put kitty out, covered him again in his crib & went out, he made not a word of complaint, kissed me & said good night over again & went to sleep.  His bowels are in a better state than ever before since his sickness. He runs all over the yard & garden very rarely touching any plant without leave. Do not fail to write often, some of you - & we will try to do the same - my condolations & congratulations to Nettie. I want to see her! I am worried for fear Persia won't come here & will feel hurt - there is the little bedroom (Chamber in the wall)

of the darling Gertie only gets well, as we have hope now that she will. The combine is here waiting your orders in regard to the mashing. I may find time by & by to do it, but a, at present closely driven with sewing, getting little time to work. Can you tell how much I want to see the little boys? We rode down to Mrs. Crosby's yester to see if we could get Nancy Piper when Ellen goes away - could not - they were so astonished & delighted about the twins. Samuel says he shall have to go to Milo by &by -'tis barely possible that I may got too, though not very likely. Will you please write me mother, how to color with copper-as I have forgotten. Ellen can color the yarn so if 'tis not convenient to do it there. Well good night - do write to us often, & I hope you will always have good news to write -don't get too tired Mother - you will & do, I know - take care of her Isaac, with much love, aff - Lucy.

THIS PAGE COMPLETES THE ONE 12 PAGES BACK
Lucy Sept. 1855
could not tell, but they think that she passed the kernel of corn yesterday in a partially digested state, - I think that Dr. Payne's medicine never could have reached the difficulty, but that the cod liver oil gave her strength to eject from her bowels much vile stuff, whereby they were swollen & puffed out hard as  a rock & which nothing else had in the least affected. Hattie Ely is ailing & has been several days with dysentery & their sister Mary is quite sick with fever at Binghampton, N. York. It is vexing that they could not find my letters for you, though there was little in them. Can Nettie tell where she got her calico for double dress, so I can tell where to look for it. I never saw either price before, & don't know at what place it was bought - 'tis rather doubtful if it can be matched now I think. We will endeavor to have the 
[left-hand side and top]  as Hattie goes down home every night. I had no idea of writing so much. I imagine you all have your hands full these days. With much love Aff. Lucy.

Lucy Oct. 55
Dear Mother

                                Nettie has just been writing, and has left her envelope open for me, so I'll try & write a little, though I have nothing special to say.
                               The dear ones Eliab & Maria, are in great sadness - they seem to have given up hope for Gertie, and truly there does not seem to be much chance for hope. I suppose Nettie has told you of her fears. It seems strange that she should hold out so long, remaining just about so, if she is not going to be better. She is a little delicate thing, and so small, I suppose there cannot be so much change for her as for a child of larger physical development. It seems as if Eliab & Mallie & Hattie too, must get entirely worn out - she has to be carried a great deal - seems to have some difficulty of breathing at times, 

[left-hand side] Nothing it would have been to have spared Percie last summer, to what it would be now.

so that it distresses her to lie down. I can but feel anxious about Maria, she has had a very hard time, but she seems very well indeed considering all her fatigue etc. Isn't it very sad about Mr. Rider? Poor Almeda- I do think she is to be pitied most. It seems a very dark prospect before them, and how nobly they both bear their affliction. I expect Ellen will go very soon now, possibly in a week, though probably not for three weeks. How we shall miss her - we have no other girl engaged yet. Nettie did not tell me what kind, or how expensive material to get for the twin caps whether plain white silk, or figured. Will she please tell me also if she would like for Mayo a drab cap just like Percie's - there was one more in the shop precisely like his, if it is not gone. Don't you all like Mayo's dress? Hattie has given me gingham enough for Percie two aprons, a very small green & white plaid &

a brown & white similar to it. How I want to see you all maneuvering with the pair. Do they always both go to sleep at the same time? Do they ever both cry at once? O, I forgot! Isaac says they don't cry at all! Do make haste along here with them. I can't imagine how you are even going to get to Dunbarton or any where else with them, unless you box them up after the fashion of our doves when they journeyed hither. Percie yesterday spread a handkerchief over his dipper on the floor & then went peeping round on all sides of it, making believe he very ignorant, saying "I wonner what's in that dipper." One day he had just began drinking when his father began to ask a blessing - he could'nt bear to let go, but kept trying to get the tumbler down to the table so as to fold his  hands, when Samuel surprised him by getting through - then he scrabbled and put down the tumbler, folded

his hands and called out in great distress, "Father say that adin, faver say that adin." We have just got our cow home after being away five milkings - she was in pound, 1,75 to pay, but we could'nt discover who put her in - she is a very peaceable creature, and if in mischief, I suspect followed some other cow - milked only once while away. It is late now, I wish I could hand you one of our good squashes. The glory of the flower garden has departed, though many things are bright yet. With very much love to all - good night.

                                                                                                                                                                                                          Lucy.

Do write to Eliab & Maria. 'Tis little any earthly friend can comfort them & for my own part, I feel that I may not intermeddle with their grief, that I cannot truly sympathize, having never had their experience, & you have been very near to it. But how little, almost

Lucy Oct. 16 55

                                                                                                                             Bangor Oct. 16, 1855

Dear Mother

                           We arrived at home about 5 o'clock after a tedious ride - we stopped an hour or more at Corrinth. The travelling was bad, the horse lazy (or sick), the air extremely chilly & uncomfortable, Percy heavy (I carried him most of the way because I could keep him warmer) and Sammie very sad & unsocial. The wind blew so that I could not keep warm. I took some cold. Percie has a very bad cold yet - coughs nearly half the night - the weather you know, has been unfavorable ever since we returned. You will think I am a great complainer, but I hope to feel better by and by. You know I had not a mouthful of food cooked in the house when we got home - our

[left-hand side and top] up on the bookcase where I laid them- One will to no good in either place - If you find it please send it with the dress. Maria got a black thibet shawl with silk fringe for seven dollars- Should you like one? It seems as if a "bay state" will be too heavy to take the place you need between cloak and mantilla. A thibet long shawl would be very nice only so expensive. In haste - with love to all - daughter Lucy.

girl can not come til tomorrow, and I have found rather hard times to get along. When we got here, I had Percie all wrapped up till Sam'l made a fire & milked the cow, then gave him his supper & put him to bed, and laid on the lounge while Sam'l borrowed bread and got supper. It began to rain just before we got home, & rained so hard that they could not send up food from Eliab's, as they intended till next day. Yesterday, because all the tomatoes were spoiling, I made preserves & ketchup, and feel about done over today - but have nothing to do but rest, as Mallie is going to send up our dinner, and a woman is here washing & cleaning up. The girl Caroline expected to come yesterday, but could not till tomorrow. I am much afraid you worse & sick, being awake so much nights, while I was there Sammie seems a
[[THIS LETTER IS POSSIBLY CONCLUDED IN LUCY'S LETTERS PART 4 DATED 1856? FOLLOWING A LETTER WITH A POEM ENTITLED ? Jos. Newton]]

Sat. morn

Dear Brethren

            I rec'd a bundle from Joseph last night, for which I am much obliged. The bosoms are done, and I sent by Mr. Dorr this morning for some starch to do them up, before I knew that Mr. Wiley was going down. I was in a hurry and never thought to tell Dorr to go to Brown's, but perhaps he will.
           I borrowed some thread and had got the shirts most done when ? came. I can finish them today as I do not keep school. I will  out them in Sherburne's field and whiten them there till I have a chance to send them down. I thought at first I would keep the rest of the cloth for myself, but it is rather too thick and coarse to answer my purpose, and I will make another pr. of whites for one of you. Tell me if you want them. It took six yds for yours and there are consequently

nine left. I shall want to get some cloth for myself one of these days, but have nothing particular to do now-adays so if you either of you want any bosoms collars or anything made, send them along. I've got a pr. of stockings most done. Do either of you want them? Why don't you profit by Isaac's advice & walk out into the country of a Sabbath afternoon and see me? People call it only three and 1/2 miles from here to the city. I thought it was five. What are you going to do Independence Day? If there's nothing else going on where you want to go, come up here. I have from 30 to 36 scholars. Some capital singers. If I can conveniently I shall send your bosoms by our Student preacher tomorrow, that is of my starch comes in season to do them up. Am much obliged

to Joseph for his information concerning the price of salmon, herring etc. Pester him if he can't find anything better to write next time. Mr. Wiley is most ready to start - good bye Lucy.
Write often do to me.
If you have or can get any thing in the world to read do send it along. I have not a single book but Bible & school books.

E.W. Metcalf
 At. W. Brown's

{Per Mr. Wiley}
[upside down] Lucy June 20 1843?

I feel somewhat anxious about Joseph - tho' he has a pretty clear head and at least tolerably fair business capacities yet he has not a very retentive memory and he has to much upon him.
I want you should say to him that he is exhorted to "lay aside every weight,, instead of which he is adving and adding to his load of care till he has evidently got more than he can bear - tell him 'tis wrong he'll be sick or crazy or what is worse neglect his eternal interests  -d watch over him and charge him to watch over himself and have what help he needs at any rate what amount of help can ballance health or life and take care of yourself, and to write to me more. A.M.M.

                                                                                                             Sept. 8th 1847.                                 [pencil] put Sam's letter in Office or home to him, as you please.

Dear Brethren etc.

                        Rec'd Joseph's letter last night at midnight. Charles was called as witness, some trouble between Webb and Nason - did not get home till midnight. You must not be hurried Joseph. You will be sick I am afraid. 
                       Isaac will probably send for some of his things here and I will send shirts bosoms etc. Then if he takes these shirts here you must send me more linen to make some for you, must'nt you? It seems Moses goes sooner than you expected. Mrs. Wilder died suddenly Monday a shock of numb palsy. Wilder of this town

Lucy & Mother 
Sep 8 1847


                  Mrs. E.M. Metcalf
                             Bangor

Lucy June 1839
but lots of Ellises go. [in pencil] We have got two pretty beatiflies of Libby's, as ever you saw in your life. We had but had one of them killed. Sister Lute.
Dear Isaac Brother

              I can't fix one of Joe's steel pens on. So a wrong stick, and he is using the right one, so I have to hold the pen right in my fingers, but I guess I won't any longer. So now I'll begin with the tother one. Isaac, I can tell you something that is very good news to me. I don't know as you will care about it either way.
              The "folkses" have sent for me to go to Boston to help Almeida do her work, Although I expect I shall see you 'face to face' & tell you about it before you will read this ere epistle. So no more of that now.
             "Brother Joe" has wrote or written so much to you that I suppose he has told you all the news. But I believe he has not told you about the "new neighbors." There is Austin & Mellen Rye & Barnard, Warren, Enoch, Augustus and Edward Ellis. They are trying to learn to navigate I guess, for they are down in the brook, paddling about on a raft that they made, every rainy day and half the time beside, most.
             Dolly has fatted up at a great rate; Mr. Shaw has offered Charles 20 dollars for her, but he asks 25. By the time he wants her again he will ask 30, I suppose. There has been a tall freshet here. The water did not quite cover our Intervale, but did Mr. Ellis's. Mother wrote to James and "amongst um" to let little Lucy come here with Martha when she comes back. but they said No. We did not expect they would let her come however. I don't know as Marm told you that Martha Lee and Moses G. are going or rather have gone with Naomi to Charleston Hospital. Is'nt it a pity I could'nt have known they wanted me there this Summer, soon enough to have gone with Martha? What beautiful showers we had the 2ed of June, didn't we? only the ground was so full of Water, that it did not seem to do much good.
             'Ieus' why don't you buy ruled paper? it is so much better to write on, and does not cost but a little more than the other. I went to Sebec to meeting the 19th of May. Mr.Sewall preached.
               I expected to start for Boston, the 6th of this month, but Mr. True Stubbs had the promise of our waggon to go to Brighton, so I could not.

June 4th We received your letter last night. Mr. Everett and Jim Dennett had the waggon. Jim he is going to Boston. was on his

way then. I have been aching to write to you as you know & always am to somebody this great while but could think of nothing in the world to write. But I thought Joseph knew about the farm best, & he would write that.
But I can tell you about the Posy Patch: it was planted a good while ago and the things have come up nicely. There is a round bed in the middle with the Peony in it, & then a wide path round that coming out, in corners so, as to leave it sq: then east and west of the Peony is a pink root, and in each of the corners made by the path the Foxglove, Mullen Pink, Columbine and Sweet William are put. They are stretching up terrible fast: the rest is divided in Oblong beds, save 2 square ones & the southern wood in the two south corners & the Aarons rod in two north ones. I don't know as you will understand how I mean but you will see if you come home in August.
I wish I was going to be at home when you are, but I suppose I shall not. If I go soon, I guess Ann will come sooner than she at first said so as to be here while you are at home. That is not a very pretty stock. If I had staid at home this Summer, I should have 
Mr. Isaac Metcalf.
Bangor Me.
[upside down] the postage paid
made you another prettier one. Arter I get to Boston, Ann & I will write you tall letters once in a while. Do you like your place now as well as you did the other? What a lovely summer day it is today is'nt it; though it is hot enough to melt us all. The Peony has got a great bud on it. We send the bundle by Pat Hobbs. I suppose the word or two that I scratched in a great hurry puzzled you more than it did you good, did'nt it? Ellen Lee is going to keep school at the mills this summer, and Seers Frost's wife's sister is going to keep our school at the corner. [pencil] June 6th the Skeeturs is a eatin of me up. It is as much as I can do to defend myself from 'em. June 10th Ellen Lee begins her school to day. Our began the first Monday of this month. None of us go to the

Milo July 18th 1842.

Dear Isaac

                   We received your letter dated July 4th on Thursday the 14th of July. The lines were few and far between I thought. It did not look as brother Isaac's letters to home generally do, it seems to me. We will receive it, however on the supposition that you were so sleepy that you had but a few thoughts, as I doubt not you are a great part of the time nowadays, notwithstanding some of your boasting speeches in time past, with regard to your triumphs over Morphus. I am afraid you will go without sleep so much that you will always suffer for it, and be a sleep dull-eyed looking fellow, if you are not one in reality. Why don't you ask Mrs. Cutter to let you have a room down stairs when the heat would not trouble you so bad. You might use it days, if they do want it nights. 
                I suppose the folks at Dover that you wanted to see most, were Charles, Joseph, Eliab and I. We some expected to see you there. Mr. French and sisters were there from Exeter; Charles fixed two seats into the waggon & went with both horses. Arnold Sargent & Sarah Jameson were married in the morning by Mr. Fop. Naomi & Theodore went together, in company with us/ Mr. Sanborn of Levant delivered a very good Oration, (so they all said.) I did not hear the whole of it, as Mr. S. stood on the roof of a house, and the congregation assembled round him on the ground, and I could not stand out then but a short time. It was said that 3 or 4 thousand partook of the Coulition dinner, as they called it, (25 cents a ticket) We all took dinner out doors with them, but were sorry we did, for it was a miserable mess, the whole of it, hardly fit to eat, and not near enough of that. A shower came up just as we had finished our report and I was obliged to flee to the house, so I did not hear the toasts, which I suppose were the best part of the whole. The boys said the first one, (just as they had eat up all there was & there was not a piece to be had) was

[left-hand side]Little Lucy & James eat some green currents Saturday & have not been very well since.The rest of us are all well as usual. Write soon

"Peace, peace when there is no peace," very appropriate I thought; another "The Washingtonians: we wish them nothing worse than that they may eat this dinner over again," Another, "Martha Washingtonian today, and Martha washing petticoats tomorrow" Another "The ladies of Piscataquis; they are all temperance men." etc. etc. I should thunk tjere was, as you may say, " incalculable injury done to white dresses and silk bonnets."

                                            Harriet Hoxie and Charles Howard were squared together on a few days since, by C.G. Fop.
                                 Bowen went home the week after you went away. I went too, and staid a few days to get him contented in his new place of abode. He seems quite contented now, though yesterday noon I went in to see him and he would not go from me to his father or mother. Mr. Sewall was there, and after looking at him a few minutes, baby went to him. He appeared to think that, Mr. S. was Charles, for he never will go to a stranger at all. There have been 3 or 4 deaths in Milton of scarlet fever since Maria Kimball died. Annah Cain died last week of it., having been sick only three days. She did not have her reason after she was taken sick.
                Mr.Cain has buried eight children before, and they were all taken up and buried with Annah in the same grave. There is now only William left, and he is  very sick with the same disorder, as is also Mrs. Cain.
                  There was a meeting last Saturday for the examination of any who wished to write with the congregational church, Major Furber, Mr. Fop and his wife and Eliab came forward, were examined, and prepared for admission yesterday. Olive Furber has returned and I hoped that she and Theodore would offer themselves for examination, but they did not. There is to be another meeting soon, and I hope some others will come forward then. the Dr., Theodore & Olive, Lucretia Haskell, Sarah Jane Stanchfield, Alice Sargent, and Marshall and Abby & Maria are all, I believe, indulging hope. Mr. Billington has come out at last, a decided Universalist. There have been eight persons baptised by imersion seven of whom have united with the Baptist church; the other, Jane Carver, did

not because her father was not willing. Ellen Lee has recovered from her insanity entirely, but her health is very feeble. Mrs. Sparhawks step daughter is at Col. Sus.  I suppose you want to know all about the farming business, but I cannot tell you much about it- I believe the boys have got most done hoeing. The black heifer's calf is being fatted for veal - be killed in a few days.

             Mr.Sewall was saying yesterday that in Brownville there had been a great effort made by the methodists to induce the converts to join their church, (something with them, I conclude,as it has been here with the Baptists) and Mr. S. said he had kept silent, let things go on in their own way, and had very little conversation with any of them until requested by their parents. The other day he spoke with Chase Page and some others about the duty of joining some church, asked them why they had not etc. they said they had been trying to be methodists. "Well, how did you make it" said he, "I could'nt make it go" He said Chase Page either had or was going to unite with his church. You did not write anything about your ?  Isaac, but I do hope you continue steadfast, if you have decided to be a follower of the Savior, do not hesitate to let it be known wherever you are. Let the world know you are a Christian; not only tell them of it, but let them see it by the difference in your character and actions, A half-way christian cannot have much enjoyment in any way. Conscience reproaches them continually - they cannot enjoy the world, even as well as before they before they began to be christians, and they cannot derive that happiness from God which they could, if they lived in more constant communion with him. I know I do not have so much, not near as much happiness & enjoyment of religion as I might have & should have if I was more devoted in the service of God, more faithful in duty, more content & fervent in prayer, & less taken up with the trifling & foolish things of earth. And yet my heart is so prone to sin, so forgetful of God, that notwithstanding I know the trouble & sorrow it occasions, I am so often led astray, that I am often led to fear for myself & almost think it impossible that I have ever truly given my heart to God. I entreat you, Isaac never to neglect secret prayer - prayer is the life of the soul. If secret prayer is neglected the heart

and the affections will grow cold. The vital force of religion is gone. If we do habitually neglect secret prayer we have reason to tremble for our selves that we are not and never have been real Christians. {"Prayer is the Christian's vital breath

                                          The Christian's native air;
                                          His watchword at the gates of death
                                          He enters heaven with prayer."


L.H. Metcalf                                                                                                  10
July 20th 1842

                                               Milo Me'        Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf
                                                July 20               Exeter
                                                                              Maine

Care of Mr. John Cutter.

                                                                                              Exeter

[upside down] You wished a bundle sent immediately, but did not write of what it should be composed. We concluded however that the key was the principal thing, and Mr. Cutter said he sent that as Charles directed him. If you want anything else tell us what, and it shall be forwarded immediately. I suppose you know that Charles has gone to Boston after work as he could get none at Bangor. I must say finis.

                                                                                                                    Your ever affectionate Sister Lucy.

Milo May 14th 1842

Dear Sister Ann & Brother Isaac,

                       You request long letters & I seem to be the most unoccupied with work and care, of any of the folks; so I suppose it devolves on me, as usual, to be news-bearer etc. for the family.
                      Well, - ; A Mr.Heald, from Harmony, came here Thursday morning to see Charles, stating that he (or his son, I believe they are in partnership) had taken the Grist Mill for a year, and wished to take the Carding & Cloth dreping Mill too. So they talked and talked (as you know how) a long time, then went down to the mill, examined the machinery etc, etc, Yesterday he came again, talked all the afternoon, and staid all night. This morning they wrote an agreement, each took a copy, and he went off. Charles has let him the mill for one year, and I believe partly agreed to for 5 years, though it is not concluded, and will not be until they see how matters will turn out a little. Charles is to furnish materials, for repairing the mill, and Mr. Heald is to do the work, and pay 50.00 a year in money for the rent. Mr. H. appears to be a very clever, good sort of a man, a kind of Thomsonian doctor, for his own family; I don't know how much farther his practice extend. His business has been for some time repairing machines here & there -, though he has built machinery, he says, home. He's got a wife & eight children, to move here. I should think him about 40 or 45 years old by his looks, though he has been sick considerable & that may occasion him to look older than he really is. Now I will tell you what I should have told at the beginning - that we recieved the bundle & letter by Mr. Cutts, which we are much obliged. Mother will get the Vest made as soon as she can, but Persis Sargent has been sick & I suppose is not able to do it yet, & Almeida has neglected her work so much to attend meeting that she is very much hurried & cannot do it. The Richards will be very acceptable to Charles I do not doubt. I should think it would be far cheaper to buy them ready made, than to buy the linen & make them if, (as I believe you wrote), you got them for 1/ apiece. I wish, Isaac, if you can conveniently, you would before you come home get me a Hymn book. I want a small one, perhaps 4 inches long or so - if you have ever noticed Ellen Lee's you know what I want. We need another one, as the leaves are many of them out of one of ours.
                          The boys have brought the Hydrangea home; it is alive & well - several new shoots have sprung up. I hope, Ann, you will think of me with a feeling of commiseration, as the crisis, as Joe calls it, is approaching. O, botheration, and after that time for a fortnight, & what misery shall I not under? in the first place the pleasures of anticipation, you know are very great; and then, & then the awful reality; when the prodigy, or as Mother expresses it with more propriety, the prodigal , actually appears before my wondering eyes. But let this disagreeably tough momentous subject be banished from our minds. Charles has finished plastering - the house is all done excepting the doors, shelves in the closets,

and painting. It is not probable that it will be completed in season for us to move before the crisis, so we shall e'en stay in the shell & make no attempt to hatch or crawl out prior to that period. Afternoon Mother & Charles have just concluded not to try to move till just before haying, as the spring work is driving, so they think it inexpedient; as it is put off so long, I think it doubtful whether we get started before Snow comes, so I am going to do my best endeavours to fit up our parlor suitable for the reception of company. The boys are ploughing a spot in the north field for a garden, as the place by the house is so weedy. The boys have brought in several kinds of flowers this Spring - I suppose you have Lilacs. I have begun to collect specimens for an Herbarium. When you come home, Ann we will study Botany together, and when we get a suitable book, we will have a nice Herbarium like Joseph's & go snacks getting specimens. I don't expect to do much gardening this summer for lack of a good place & strength to take care of it; but I must entice Jimmy or somebody else to make me some flower boxes. I myself, I all alone made Eliab a pr of shirts entire, in 5 days this week, besides doing several other little matters, & Joseph has engaged the S. Circle to make him a pr. which they will finish next time they meet I suppose. I intended to have gone last time but it was too windy.

                         The revival in Brownville is more interesting than ever it is said, especially in the north part, so much so, that Mr. Sewall & Wilkins could neither of them leave to come here this week & there has been no minister here except a Mr. Mayherd, (young man from Charleston) who was here two or three evenings. Major Furber thinks he experienced religion last week. When he was sick a year ago, he made many promises with regard to how he would spend his life if it was spared, which people think he has not performed; but he said at the commencement of the meeting that he thought he had kept them all. He now thinks differently about it. Mr. Richards says when this meeting is done he is going to hold a protracted meeting.
                    You did not write anything about the vest which you sent up - do you want it made & sent back or shan't you want it till you come home. Monday morn. Mr. Cutter & Aron are going back this afternoon & we will send this by then. I went to meeting yesterday all day. Mr. Thibbets from Exeter preached in the forenoon & Mr. Strout from Brdaford in the afternoon - preached an excellent sermon from 1 Corinthians 1-30 - using up the Universalists, Deists, Infidels etc. etc. entirely.
                    Amongst us ll we have made an awful looking letter I think. I fear you will not be able to read it - write soon - particularly

[right-hand side] Ann we want to hear all about your school troubles & trials, employments & pleasures & all the rest.
Nota bene Isaac! Charles left his pant out? (and gloves in the pocket) at the tavern where he stay'd ? I believe wants you should go directly and see about it he sent by Mr. Welch but he could'nt remember the place and you were up the river he said, I'm very much afraid he never'll get it again.

Well we gave sowed 3 1/2 bush of peas  up to the head of interval - hauled out 7 1/2 loads of manure & ploughed a garrden - sum total of farm proceedings. We callcalate that the farm is divided near where you proposed Viz: from pine state down 2d rush? across the bridge to Elm just below the thorn tree twixt barley & oats. Thence in a right line to the N. bank of Piscataquis river. We i.e. El. & Joe want some peas to sow on ground to be broken up next Thursday at above the brook but peas are peculiar scarce none in Milo. Can be had in Jo. Chace of Sebec for Cash $1.00 per bush I suppose. Were foolish undertaking with regard to ? house has belated? as about farm operations & everything else. Folly in the extreme had been exhibited in our hopperations this spring. We are backward in ploughing & sowing & have not procured our few wheat ? & peas & now it is too late to bi them ? at all. I m in such a hurry I cannot tell what to write (nor should to write it with docity or imposure  so   Goodbye  Joseph M. Metcalf 
Mr. Nyman has got home - came here this morning & was very much struck up when he found that Charles had let the mill go to Heald. you know Charles told him he would give him 10 dollars to tell what sum he would give or tale - & this morning he told C. that he would give or take 500,00. Now C. says he is in a quandry having let the mill to Mr. Heald - Charles want to buy it if he can pay with horse, hay etc. but I think he has had trouble enough with the old mill and I wish he would sell for 500.00, pay his debts, build him a house, buy him a wife & settle down in life & try to enjoy himself a little, after having had so many vexations etc. so long.
I can't write a good long letter this time either but my Dear Son, I want to intreat you to beware and not neglect your duty dont begin to do it as you make your ? purpose rest on your usefulness - I trust you are setting out in a new way careful to begin right in every respect and your journey will be far less difficult and dangerous. your way may often be dark therefore make constant use of your lamp, the oil of it will never fail if constantly us'd but unlike some other lamps the more it is us'd the more light it will give & moreover in connection with constant fervent prayer it will be good for you to make you strong and healthy all your journey through.

L.H. Metcalf
May 14th 1842
Milo


                                      Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf
                                                Bangor
                                                        Maine

Favored by Mr. Cutter

Bangor

Milo 1843    1843 Foxcroft
Dear Brother Issac

                                As Joseph is going to Foxcroft today, Mother takes this favourable opportunity to rebuke you, through me, for studying too hard, and doing sundry other evil deeds which she suspects you are guilty of; such as neglecting to call upon certain young ladies etc. etc. the which according to all rules of politeness you are in duty bound to do. Also when we earnestly desire, and have frequently requested to know what studies you are pursuing, you have in all your epistles, neglected  to communicate said information. You are therefore rebuked accordingly, while at the same time we hope you will do better in future. By no means stand upon your dignity with regard to school, for it will be a slippery foundation. Ann says, presume not to ask more than twenty dollars or thereabouts, lest you should lose the school, as the renowned C.M. Stevens, could get only twenty, and it will be vain for your to aspire to be greater than he! Ann says be sure and engage that or some other school speedily lest all the good ones should be engaged.  Also the one at 4 corners, for Joseph if possible. We have thought considerable lately (or Mother and Ann have) of taking the baby (Eliab) and going to Massachusetts to spend the winter; Mother & Ann would visit about, and Eliab would board at Uncle Jacob's and go to the high school this winter, and in the spring go in with Chauncey Chase or some one else in Boston as Apprentice. This is all very fine to talk about, but I fear the plan will not go into execution for lack of funds. We want to know what you are studying, and why you
