                                                          Maine                                                          July 11th  1846
                                                                                                                          Bangor 29

La Grange Aug. 29th 1846

Dear Brother

                 On my return from Milo on the  I found your last good long letter awaiting me. Many thanks for the same, dear brother. I had an opportunity to go home with Dr. Kimball, & accordingly dismissed my school for three days while Ann was at home. Had a fine time went blueberrying twice and did not get a dozen berries either time. Too late in the season for them. Charles and Albina came and brought me back Sabbath night after meeting. My school closes next Tues. I long for the time of my release to arrive. Every family in the District without an exception have beset me to come again next Summer. The Agent tried to make me promise; says I shall have as much wages as I can get anywhere else, more or less! I conclude from all this that I have given good satisfaction.
             Your "Proverbial Philosophy" I am much pleased with. Should admire to get hold of the book. The "Crock of Gold" I have read. Came across it here in Lagrange. Like it very much. The person of whom I borrowed it had not read it, thought 'twas'nt much - nothing but a story etc.  I thought from my knowledge of the individual it would be an excellent plan of he would read it or & put it to practical use! I gave him " a piece of my mind" when I returned the book.
              Your unsealed letter was postmarked in due form at Brunswick. No harm if a few Lagrangers did read it! I suppose you know that Mr. Walker is remarried. Joseph writes about 

[left-hand side] I do want to send you some of my money, but I am owing Ann most pay of it & don't know as it will be possible. I am very sorry you are obliged to leave College this fall for money, when there is so much of it in the world! But there's no consolation to it. If you go to Turner I would make them give you more than last year.

it this; "an evening meeting was in the vestry. After service the parson announced that a solemn ceremony would tale place. Asa and his elect lady came forward and were wedded then and there. or to speak more concisely, they approximated and were hitched." Droll fellow, Jo. I had the pleasure of seeing Daniel Holman & his "elect lady" the last time I was at Milo. Rather an old looking bride considering the youth and beauty of the bridegroom.

          Perhaps am account of one of my visits would not be uninteresting to you. Last Sat. night I was invited to a place (where is a grand house & everything nice & comfortable) to tarry all night & go to meeting next day at the corner. When I got part way there I learned that the lady of the mansion had been suddenly called away by sickness, so I could'nt go there.  It was so far (about two miles) that I could'nt very well go home, besides as my intention was to spend the night was known, I should give offence if I did not stop were I then was. (You know, as "Aunt Kesiah" says "folks like to be taken notice of if they are poor.") Accordingly I tarried.  A very 'exiguous" house, containing one room, and I suppose one chamber, as I saw persons ascending and descending a ladder occasionally, also a trap door through which ingress and egress was had to a small hole under ground, by some denominated a cellar, wherein was deposited milk, butter and divers other edibles wherewith the inhabitants were wont to satisfy the demands of nature. The room was very little, if any, larger than a large bedroom. It contained "the dressers" and a sink, some chairs and a table. In one end was a tolerably huge fireplace and in the other a bed & trundle bed. Overhead was a pole whereon were hung sundry garments for the use of the family. A

large basket containing bedding etc. was suspended by the wall; a gun for "mutual defence" rested near the ceiling on two hooked sticks, and various bunches of yarn, the result of the good woman's industry, hung about the room. A broken candle stick hung on a strap of leather, prepared for the purpose, over the fireplace. A wide shingle put in a chink between two boards formed the mantel piece, upon which were a couple of well used pipes, some tobacco and a dirty newspaper. When the season arrived for returning to rest, the good man crawled up the ladder to bed, resigning his more comfortable situation below, to me. His loving spouse did then dress the bed anew in a cleanly manner, out of pure regard to my feelings probably, a deposit a pretty clean little baby therein. She then drew forth the trundle bed, and snugly bestowed three more into that, after which she extinguished the fore, and proceeded to unrobe and betake herself to rest, desiring me to do the same. She is a very kind, good-hearted woman, and showed me every attention in her power; was very fearful lest I should not rest well, and for that reason, I suppose, I could not close my eyes in sleep till past the "noon of night." I thought I had been "brought into straits" before, but this outdid them all. Alas! for the miseries of a country school ma'am! Say you not so? I rose in the morning, partook of a very good breakfast, went to meeting, and got back to my boarding place at night alive! Some people have trials, difficulties & inconveniences  which even we know little about. I had had an excellent boarding place, as good as I could wish with the exception of seven noisy children! which, with you, I suppose, would be no small objection.

        I do wish I could get more good books to read. Really need some.

Excellent. "Safer is he that storeth knowledge than he that would makest for himself." I mourn over our deficiency of intellectual food, but cannot help it. What excessively warm weather & what a quantity of it, we have this summer. Wish C. had planted more corn! I wish you could get the school in Brunswick that you spoke of. Too bad you have to be out of College so much. Ezra Barker is going to teach a high school at the village this fall & has engaged the village school for this winter. It seems friend Tash's plan did not succeed. Write soon - Aff. Sister Lucy.
Sept. 10th 1846                   Forwarded   Way 6 5 /11                                                            Miss L.H. Metcalf
Via Turner                                                                                                                                       Lagrange
Topsham                                                                                                                                               Milo

                                                                                                                                                   Aug 29th. Sept. 5th.

Bradford Me
Sept 5/46
Forward to 
Sept.9  Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf   Topsham Maine
[right-hand side] Mehitable Furber, Naomi Hill, Eliza Wilder and I don't know who else, are soon to start for Lowell Factory. I do very much wonder at Mehitable, as good a home as she has. Her father nor mother, neither of them want her to go. She knows not what is for her good, in my opinion. Don't think she will stay long. Intends to stay a year, then come home & go to Wisconsin.
[bottom of page upside down]Milo Sept. 11th Got home day before yesterday. Charles was most sick, feverish, & in pain all over, but is much better, quite smart now. The children have all got the Whooping cough, Jenny & all. Lucy & Lisy are the worst, as yet - not very bad.  What a beautiful rain we are having today! Very much needed. Everything drying up. Quite sickly in divers places owing to so much hot dry weather, & no thunder to purify the air. C. has got all his Oats harvested, safely in the barn. Intended to have got in said hay before the rain, but was sick. He has an excellent little boy. First rate fellow. Always pleasant & ready & willing. Works hard too. Never goes to meeting! Can't make him. Suppose you rec'd letters from Bangor by Mrs. Brown at Commencement.

La Grange Aug. 4th 1846

Dear Brother

             By last mail I had the pleasure to recieve your good letter, for which I most heartily thank you. But, good "Brudder" are you aware that said letter travelled all the way from Brunswick hither, minus a seal? Quite a mistake of your, was'nt it? I've been joked about open love letters considerable. It lay in the P.O. a while, then came and stopped at Mr. Trott's over night, and finally spent the day at my boarding place while I was at school! Divers people were blessed with an opportunity to peruse it, if so disposed, and I doubt not they were. Don't know how they relish your tyrade about "low wages and other folks brats" etc. , nor care, - they've no business peeping into it.
            My school is half done. I begin to peep through to the end, though the remaining four weeks look long to me in prospect. It continues pleasant as could be expected from so large a school of small scholars. I have had to punish but one yet, which I think is doing pretty well considering that I keep them in excellent subjection. I think a mild, decided government, especially for small scholars, decidedly preferable to a harsh, hasty one, don't you? I believe I have full as much patience as common people, which after all is an indispensable qualification (or quality) in a school-teacher. From my own experience I am

confident that singing is a great help to the government of a school, or at least to the order and good feeling, which in a measure prevents the necessity of government. People may laugh at the thought of my being a "music teacher," but I may use my own talents.

                   I am really attached to these children many of them, and shall feel bad to leave them, though I doubt not my sorrow at parting with them will be more than counterbalanced by my joy at getting home. 
                I have really a very fine boarding place as far as people are concerned. Mrs. Kenney is truly one of the "excellent of the earth," quite a lady. an old school teacher native of Dover N.H., has lived in Boston considerable.
            Mr. K. is a tall, straight, prosperous, happy farmer, with a good wife, seven pretty children, three hundred acres of excellent land, good buildings and plenty of money, which last is a good thing. He has sowed eighty bushels of Oats this year - look splendidly.
            Sunday is the most trying day to me here. People visit all day without distinction of age, sex, or condition. We have meetings every Sabbath, - but more whereby I m greatly edified, - free will, Baptists & Universalists, not very enlightened as a general thing. Pretty good society I conclude, however, considering the newness of the place and called an excellent farming town.
         I don't cease to 'hector' Charles about 'Tiger.' Albina understands all about it. He brought her home to stay all night Sat. when I was at home. They would both far better as far as I am concerned, unquestionably , if they

come out boldly & be more open about their proceedings. Do you get any letters from Milo? I don't. Eliab is culpable. Say you not so? How does your health do this warm weather?

              With regard to the "rude blow to your first ambition," I would'nt allow myself to care any thing about it. I feared when you was at home you were making too much calculation upon it. A knock at the school 'us door 'tother day. Opened. An old lame codger, with striped shirt & tarpaulin hat sought admittance. After he entered the house I recognized him as one of the Select men & S.S. Comm of La Grange, & accordingly paid him all due deference. The scholars 'ris' at his approach, and again when his image (and superscription) receded from view. He took my name, promising to write a Certificate, & get another signer. Asked me not a question. This is my fifth school & have never been examined but once - that was to teach the Hobb-landers!
             I desire your opinion. Suppose I give tickets to the scholar who stands at the head the most nights in a week: shall he who recieves the ticket, or he who leaves off at the head Sat. night, if it be another one, be sent to the foot Mond. night?
             Perhaps it may interest you to know that before I came down here I filed away all the letters nicely. I have written but eighteen letters including this nor rec'd but ten since I came here! Am going up to the P.O. Aug. 5th about two miles tomorrow night (mail day) to put this in the Office & get some letters for me (I hope). My school will close, I expect, the 28th of Aug. Write to me once more at any rate before tis done won't you. And forget not to seal it! The Owl is a very fine idea, Transcendentalism

or not. This day Wednes. Aug. 5th has been very oppressively warm here. How at Brunswick? It seem if I could hardly stay here to drill these 'young 'uns' three weeks longer.
Well good bye      Very affectionately 

                                                            Sister Lucy.

Aug. 9th
1846
Board Coll.              La Grange                        Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf                                          Miss L.H. Metcalf

                                  Augt 7                                Brunswick                                                     La Grange
                                                                                         Maine                                              Aug 4th 1846

Milo Oct. 16th 1846.

Dear Brother Isaac            

                                   I believe the last letter I wrote you from home was about - a good while ago! wasn't it? I wrote part of a letter when I first went to Bangor, expecting Ann would finish it and sent it in answer to yours which was recieved the day after I got there, but her time was so taken up that it had not been written when I came away, on the 7th inst. You have probably recieved it however, before now.
                  I had a very pleasant visit of a little more than a fortnight; enjoyed myself much. Helped Ann some in school, practiced drawing some myself etc. Got my Dag. while there for 1.75! It seems a long, long, time since we have heard from you. Why are you so silent. We want much to know how you succeed in your school etc. Day before yesterday we (that is Charles, Albina and I together with sundry other Milo folks) went to Dover to the dedication of the new Masonic Hall. Masons and Sons of Temperance own it together I believe, but the former, being the 'elder Sister,' dedicated it. Their ceremonies etc. were really amusing, and yet seemed quite solemn. Old Capt. Greenleaf was "Mot Worshipful Grand Master," and Squire Holmes seemed to be pretty high in office,  as also Jo Chase. "Father Kittredge" Lawyer Chandler, Seth Carpenter, and John S. Sayward of Bangor also Parson Averill were among the number - many others I did not know. They first put three great spermaceti candles burning, - one on each desk- then put the altar in the middle of the floor, put on their aprons, - of

which there were divers kinds, some being plain white linen, others blue silk covered with various images and devices, and others still white satin, with silver fringe and gold and silver spangles after which Capt. Greenleaf read a hymn from the "black book," which the choir sung beautifully, having prepared by rehearsal beforehand. Then they all rose and marched round the Altar till Capt. Greenleaf and Mr. Holmes had thumped solemnly three times apiece with their little wooden mallets on the desk and altar, then stopped, and Mr. Sayward came forward with a pitcher and handing it to Greenleaf, said "Most worshipful grand master I present you with a pitcher of corn etc. which Capt. G. took and sprinkled on the altar, the masons all clapped their hands and went on, going over the same meaneuvers with a pitcher of ore and a pitcher of wine, increasing the number of claps each time. Parson Averill made a prayer to begin with and read a part of Solomon's prayer at the dedication of the temple at the close. I did not like that. It seemed almost wished along with so much mummery. Well when they got through we all marched over to the Cong. meeting house, singers, Orator & chaplains, Sons and Masons and ladies, where we listened to a very excellent oration by Mr. Sayward, and some fine singing - set pieces, then marched back to the new Factory hall opposite Mr. Steven's where we had an excellent supper (Pic nic) everything in fine style. Saw Mr. and Miss Tash, the Holmes & Tower girls, Parkers, Chamberlains, Greely's and Sue Farnham to boot. Had a grand time, much better than I expected. Had quite a long dish of discourse with Abby Carpenter. She is engaged to Mr. Morrell, our singing master, a very fine man

I should think from his appearance: Have'nt got much acquainted with him yet. He teaches here and at Brownville.

   Every thing goes on as usual here. Naomi and Mehitable have gone to Lowell, for which I think the latter especially, together with all her folks are very blameworthy. Barker is teaching high school with eighteen scholars & Albina a low one with 25.
          Angella Dennett has gone to Boston to spend the winter. I called on her at Bangor. William Dennett has got a very fine woman I concluded. No would be aristocratic gentility about her. Visited at Mr. Pomroy's, and heard him preach several times. Crowder house the first Sab. after his return, many could not get in, no meeting at Hammond St. You have probably seen in the papers all about it. Mrs. Lee and the old Col. himself have go home from Mass. safe and sound. He saw Mr. Pomroy in Boston. Mr. Perkins is dismissed from Royalston church.
          I am in a sad hurry today and have written anything and everything without stopping to think. Mother will write a few words I guess. I rec'd your good letter the week before I went to Bangor. Thank you much. Write another soon, won't you? Almeda is demurring about going to Mass. to spend the winter. Do write soon   
                                                                                                                     Affectionately, Sister Lucy.

I have hardly a heart to write to you. I feel so tryed & troubled that I have nothing more substantial than words to send but I don't know but it will always be just so. I'll try to be thankful that you have so good a faculty and get along so well without. It seems you are very fortunate in getting that school. Do you come in contact with any really Devoted lively Christians nowadays or are there no such beings in the land. 8 week since we have had any preaching except Averill once  no society meetings, - Hiram is here yet some expect he will stay all winter. -Chas. not made out to sell the colt yet tried to make a Mr. Pratt Mrs. Weller's Agent take him instead of the oxen but he would not - S.W.F. has tried earnestly & perseveringly but has not made much progress has avowed himself a universalist & has been in a quandary - give it up I guess I don't know
[upside down under Lucy's signature] If Almeda goes to Mass. she will leave James here and carry?have? Lucy stay a year with her aunt Rachel which will do the child much good I think. C. got harvesting all done, garden seeds? all in, part of his ploughing done, has worked on the road most all the fall oxen gone now shed not done great deal to get ready for winter as usual.
[upside down]

Oct 19th 1846
Topsham

                                                     Milo Oct 17th                                                        5
                                                                                    Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf                                            Miss L.H. Metcalf
                                                                                               Topsham                                                        Milo
                                                                                                        Maine                                                 Oct. 17th 1846

Bangor Sept. 26th 1846

Dear Brother

               "Here I am. This is a very, insignificant sentence" etc. nevertheless, not unimportant. I came to B. when Joseph returned from Milo last Mond. Sept 21sr. Charles came in with both horses (tandem) and brought us. Failed in the principal object of his journey vis. to sell Donkey. Found no one who wanted him. Joseph enjoyed himself at Milo much to all appearance (that's all you can judge by in him you know) eating honey and so on.
           Charles has taken up eight hives this fall. Bees did uncommonly well this season. Had his best hive (nicest honey) robbed last week. It is too bad that he must lose honey so every year and have no clue to detect the thief. C. has prospered wonderfully about his work. He has had a good little boy. Harvesting all done - every thing in the barn - potatoes nearly all dug I believe. I do wish he could sell Donk. I am at Mr. Palmer's now with Ann & expect to go see Jos. next week & then go home. J. and E. were both here last eve - brought a letter to Ann from you. They are both in good health now.
           I rec'd a good long brotherly letter from you last week at Milo for which I heartily thank you. You therein spoke of Angella Dennett C.A. Everett etc. I have not yet called on Angella. Perhaps in different circumstances I might have done so before now, - though it has not been convenient, - but

in time past she has treated me ill in various ways - that is, slighted me and shown me that she did not care for my acquaintance. If that is her feeling, well and good. I will not fawn on her. You need'nt think me 'touchy.' I am not. Her treatment has hurt my feelings, more than once. I have ever treated her kindly, and shall continue to do so when we meet, but I am too proud - if you will call it so - to bow and cringe. Angella has a cousin visiting there Miss Sawyer no taller than Albina, & as big, every whit, as old Mrs. Davis. A fine girl I guess. Very intelligent countenance, beautiful eye, reminds me of Mrs. Pomroy. Should like to be acquainted with her.

               As for C. A. Everett, I like him very well. He is quite a talented fellow and very good company, if he is lazy. If I thought he had any books to read, I'd make the best of my way to his lodgings forthwith! I believe I wrote you that Angella has finally given him "the mitten." She was engaged to & corresponded with him until a short time before her return when she wrote him a dismissal. He says she has jilted him and done it as handsomely as a woman could! Report says now she is to be married to Daniel's wife's brother 'down south.'
       Mehitable Furber and N. Hill expect to be here next Wednes. on their way to Lowell. I can but think Mehitable is very foolish. Joseph says he'll pay for getting my 'Dag' [Daguerreotype] while I'm here, if he may have a 'lean on the image for security!"  Well good bye. Ann will finish this letter, and I'll write again after I go home which will be in a few days.                      Aff        Sister Lucy

Miss L.H. Metcalf
Bangor
Sept. 26   1846
Oct. 13

                                                    Oct. 14th 
                                                   Topsham
                                                    Brunswick

Bangor Dec. 20th / 46

Very dear Brother

               Your last letter was joyfully rec'd Thanksgiving eve, as also one from Tip Furber. I know not whether Mother or any of the folks have written to you since that time or not. For my own part I have found no time to write before, and am writing now Sabbath day between meetings when I ought to be better employed! My pen is also poor my ink not good and fingers cold, so you may expect an interesting letter.
                 If you have not had letters from home recently, you will want me to tell all the news, and if you have, you can hear it over again. Ann and Eliab went home to spend Thanksgiving week, and "Sister Albina" spent the day at our house too. A busy, confused week. Worked hard of course to get a good dinner, & harder still to eat it! Ann went home determined to take me back with her. 'Cordinly' here I am. She needed my assistance in school, and I board at a place (Sidney Thaxters, Houlon St.) where half a dollar per week is paid in tuition - three children go to Ann's school - and I knit & sew evenings to pay the rest.
               The oldest child, a girl nine years old, is lame by nature - can with difficulty walk, and one reason they wanted me to come is on account of helping her to school. I have a very pleasant situation - will be very beneficial to me on many accounts. Very clever people here I guess. Open hearted, generous sort of folks. My greatest source of uneasiness is for Mother.  She wants my company as well as help. She must feel very lonely. Do try & write to her often, won't you, also to me. We are very much indeed obliged for Proverbial Philosophy. I like it exceedingly. No book you could have sent would please us better. I help Ann some in school, & some I draw & study French. I don't know as a knowledge

of those branches will ever be any real benefit to me, but perhaps I can afford to spend my time to get them merely for pleasure, as I can do it without expense!

      I forgot to tell you that I rec'd an invitation by mail "per order of the Committee and Mr. J. Tash & C.W. Holman" to attend the scholars Pic Nic at the close of the last term; so whenn we started for Bangor, Charles got a double sleigh, took both horses and he, Ann, Eliab and I went through Dover. When we 'arrove', to our disappointments, mortification & dismay, we found the Pic Nic was the week before! Carelessness of our P.M. in not delivering the letter when Charles was at the Office, and carelessness in me in not noticing the date in reccollecting the time time the term always closes. However it was no matter, all passed off well. We saw the folks spent the night at Mr. Parker's & round about, had a fine time, beautiful weather, started next morning came through Exeter, dined at Mr. Cutter's & arrived in the "city" about eight in the evening.
     I suppose you have heard from Almeda. Don't know as you have either. Little Lucy has been very sick with lung fever, so that for some days her life was despaired of: Doctor's bill will be bad for her. I attended the Baptist Sewing Circle at Francis Shepard's the other eve, saw there one Joseph Treat, Joe's room-mate. Do you know him? Our Jos. says there have two first rate Josephs got together at Weston's! Sarah Treat is in town now at Broadstreet Moodys, our next neighbor, and relatives of Thaxter. I tell Jos. we must call on her. She is a fine young lady if report may be depended on. Such are very rare in this age of the world and should be duly appreciated. Say you not so? The week before I came from home I rec'd an application from S. Agent in Legrange to teach their school this winter. Thought I would'nt, Our people are making great preparations for Christmas. All going to a party but me. Wish you could be here & spend the evening with

[top of letter upside down]I must tell you Jos. says he has never seen but few young women that he likes any better than Sarah Treat!

me. Mr. Thaxter expended ten dollars last year in Christmas presents! He is a firm methodist. Real pleasant sociable, clever man. Next Sab. eve commences a series of Union lectures alternately at 1 PM. Pomroy's and Hammond St. I do verily believe that the prevailing opinion that our good friend Pomroy is strongly inclined to indolence is not without foundation.

       I don't think of any more news, and as for thinking enough to write any thing else, I am so hurried and my poor brain so confused it is out of the question.
      Ann's school is pleasanter then usual - few boys - about 35 scholars - no large ones. She is 'driv' of course, short days teaching school. Jos. is the same thinking, querying, studious fellow as ever - boards only two or three doors from me. Eliab prospers as usual. I have not seen him since I came here (a fortnight since) till this morn before meeting a ? five minutes, so you may conclude that in the general drive, he is 'driv', or he would call to see me oftener. My Mr. Thaxter is in company with William Jewell, corn & flour dealers. An Odd Fellow besides.
     Why don't you be an Odd Fellow or S. of T. or something so as not to differ from your brethren? People in Milo seem to be waking up a little about building a meeting house, but there is no one to take the lead unless it be Charles & he certainly cannot do much. The S. of T. hall is completed. Will probably be used for Universalist meeting house. All the new comers lately seem to be Universalists. I wish we were all fairly out of Milo. It seems probably now that C. will spend his days there. I wish he would get married & put an end to gossip.  It is high time. I rather think they will 'wed' before spring, but don't know. You must come to the wedding at any rate. Albina is teaching school in the east part of the town. Oliver Furber the small school in the Village, E. Barker the large one & Mr. Mason at the corner. I am quite ashamed of this letter, but perhaps it will be better than none, and I'll try to write again better ere long. Affectionately Sister Lucy.

[top of page upside down] Do write me a long letter soon. This has been written in no time, almost.

Dec. 26th 1846
Topsham
via Bruns.
[post mark] BANGOR ME DEC 21                                                   5

                                                          Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf                             Miss L.H. Metcalf
                                                                    Brunswick                                    Bangor
                                                                                Maine                               Dec 20th 24th  1846

Milo Nov. 30th 1846

Mr. White

      Sir
                   I rec'd your letter last evening.
                                                                                                                                     Bangor Jan'y 8th 1847

Dear Brother Isaac

                           You will excuse me for using a sheet on which another letter was commenced (a negative answer to an application from La Grange to teach school this winter) as it must be used sometime & as well now perhaps as any time. Your letter of the 26th alt. was rec'd in due season, for which please accept my hearts thanks.
              It certainly does one good to recieve letters from ones friends. As Proverbial Philosophy says, "and should it thou ask my judgement of that which hath most profit in the world, For answer take thou this - the prudent penning of a letter." What a book that is - it has something on every subject, for every occasion. So many wise sayings, beautifully though oddly expressed, and always so true to nature. I am almost afraid I shall quote it as Scripture sometime, as friend Walker's class do Shakespeare. One of them quoted a passage from that Author as Scripture. Mr. W. told him it applied very well, but was taken from Shakespeare, not Bible. The fellow turned the joke by saying that Shakespeare was quoted so often by their teacher that he supposed it might pass current!

Poor 'Asa' has no mercy shown him by any body now a days, unless it be by the members of his beloved fireside circle. I am very glad you went your journey & glad you enjoyed it so much. Wish I could have gone with you too! Am content to remain in blissful ignorance with regard to the particular business of your journey.

               Our Lowell cousins seem to be somewhat dispersed, but prosperous, notwithstanding, are they not? So you saw "Uncle Jo." Large as life, I suppose. Trafton & Richer (our old school-fellows, you know) board near by me, so near that I have the pleasure of seeing "Billy the less" every day as he passes to & from his place of business. He looks more sensible than he used to.
              I do to Singing School two evenings in a week to one Mr. Lucas from Mayo? He presented Ann with a ticket & I use it. He makes great pretensions, and is, I think, an excellent teacher, though a very disagreeable man - egotistical, self important and cross. I am in William Dow's class in Sab. School, as is also Sarah Harlow. By the way, I was informed by way of Albina Kittredge and Lucretia Hashell that you were very partial to the said Sarah, and that she was equally partial to you! Correct report or not?
          I must tell you of the splendid Antiquarian Concert at Hammond St. New Year's eve. All the old folk got together and sing all the old tunes and Anthems they could find. I do wish Mother could have heard them, she would have enjoyed it so much. Old Dr. Abbott and Dea.Thurston beat the time with so much rush I had serious fears lest they should dislocate their shoulders! 
             Dea T. sometimes beat with both hands, leaned forward with head up & eyes shut, and while singing some of the most enrapturing  strains actually stood on tiptoe. They made music I assure you, but it was fine to see how excited some of them were. Object of the concert, to provide fuel for destitute families. House crowded and single tickets 25 cts. I went with Mr. Thaxter

He is a real kind, noble -souled, generous, fellow I think. I like him much and her to. Spose you had a bit of a present New Years did'nt you. Wish we could some of us send you more and oftener. Christmas eve I found a Muff box in the entry, directed to me, containing a very pretty black muff. A very acceptable present indeed as I needed one much. I leave you to judge whether brother Jos. or old "Sandy Claws" himself placed it there.

              Last year Mr. T. laid out upwards of ten dollars in Christmas presents. Charles was down here this week. I saw him but a very few minutes. Guess he and Mother are rather lonely sometimes. He ought to get married.

                 Jan'y 14th - Jos. is going to send a letter to you sometime "fore soon" and I'll put mine in with it, though perhaps if I'd waited a while I might have had some more news to write. You must excuse me from writing a great deal this winter as I hardly have a moments time I can call my own except Sundays. Write to me again soon will you - Good bye - affectionately
                        Sister Lucy.

Jan. 18th 1847
Topsham

                                                                 Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf                                                Miss L.H. Metcalf
                                                                   Brunswick                                                             Bangor
                                                                       Maine                                                                Jan 8th 14th 1847

Milo March 20th 1847.

Dear Brother Isaac

                    I want to write you a good long letter, but I have been so confused with the events of the past three or four weeks, that I hardly know where to begin, or what to say. However I'll try to communicate what I wish, though not, perhaps, in a very systematic manner.
                 Ann & I came home Monday Mar. 1st ( a very cold; windy day) with Charles. About a fortnights before that, little Freddy Thaxter died. Mr. T's youngest - a beautiful boy of eighteen months. He was sick about three weeks. I had helped take care of him some, watched one or two nights etc. and what with fatigue, excitement and a severe cold, got "run down," so that for a week before I came home was quite sick, threatened with fever etc. but as good luck would have it, happened to be at Mrs, Shepherd's, and she nursed me up nicely was very kind indeed. Got a little better so I could come home, but took more cold in the way, and was quite unwell for a while, cough, pain in the side etc. so that sad to relate, I could not attend the wedding! I am now quite smart, only have hardly regained my strength.
              Well as I said, we came home Monday, and the next week Teusday John Cutler & wife happened along on a visit, - they went to iron mines Wednes. came back & staid till Friday. Thurs. about noon Mar.

11th , who should come but Joseph, Eliab & Lizzie Quimby. Liz came to visit here, at Mrs. Lee's, Greenleafs etc. We were then all in the midst of extensive preparations of all sorts, house all in confusion, of course, Lizzie took off her things, got warm & in less than an hour was setting tables, sweeping etc. in spite of anybody. A real lively, homespun, pretty body, at home anywhere. Make Eliab a capital wife, if they should  make such a bargain- Good deal of joking on both sides. She insists that they are engaged etc.! Well the same day about 5 o' P.M. all but Mr. & Mrs. Cutler, Mother & I, repaired to Father Kittredge's, at which time and place Charles & Albina were made husband & wife by parson Sewall. Olive Furber & Liz Quimby, brides maids, Jos. & Eliab Groomsmen. After the ceremony they all came directly home. where were assembled some 30 or so, of our friends & neighbors "to spend the evening. Ellen Brown, Greenleaf's, Hills, Dennetts, Furbers, Hartwells etc. We had a good supper, a merry company & every thing passed off beautifully, better than we any of us expected, though I did'nt enjoy it very much because I could'nt be about among them much. Next day friday Mr. Cutler went home, & Sat. Joseph, Ann & Eliab went back to Bangor. I intended to go at the same time but was not well enough. Lizzie Quimby spent almost a week here, went away last Teusday. We get along very snug & pleasantly with Albina. Pleasant, willing to do as folks tell her. She & Charles enjoy themselves finely - "Honey

moon" you know. :Last Wednes. night Mr. Shepherd from Bangor with whom Ann boards, spent the night here. We wished you, and Almeida too, could have been here on the memorable occasion. Charles gets married so seldom that I really felt quite disappointed at not seeing him. We often talk about it & feel very bad that there cannot be more done for you, but know not how to help it. There is justly due you from Charles a hundred dollars, but with the present peculiar management of affairs here, it seems to be hard work each year to live along, & pay the taxes. I did feel really grieved when the colt was sold & found that nothing was going to you, and Charles seemed to feel as bad as anybody but it seemed impossible to do it. I cannot but think that if some men had the management of C's property it might be made to yield much more profit; still I do not attribute blame to him. He is not gifted by nature with a capacity for "getting a living" as some men are & for that reason I see no prospect that it will ever be different with him. Nevertheless, when worst comes to worst, he generally contrives to get along some way & do what must be done; - for that reason, I do hope & believe he will be able to do something for you this summer. I think he wants to as much as we can want to have him. I wish it was in my power to help you, but instead of that I have to be helped by the boys. Hardly know what will become of me if my health is not going to be good. Ann is very anxious to have me go back to Bangor, as she needs my help, and 'tis a good chance for me, - I think I shall go in a week or two if

I am well enough. It has been very sickly in Bangor this winter. Lucy complains very frequent. Dr. Mc. Ruen as you have probably seen by the papers, has gone to Scotland on a visit. Daniel Dow was buried yesterday. Been sick a long time - Consumption. This is a hastily written & horrid looking letter, but do excuse it & write me a good long one soon. I shall probably be in Bangor in the course of a fortnight.                      Very affectionately, Sister Lucy.
March 29th. 1847         Milo

[right-hand side] Write if you want anything we can furnish you so that it may be ready when you come.
[bottom of page, upside down]Do you hear from, or write to, Almeda very often. She does not write home often. We have written to her since the wedding. Expect a letter from her every day. Charles was much gratified with your letter to him. What about your going to New Hampshire? Don't understand it. To Jos, you wrote Vermont, to us, N.H. What is it? The Rummaries in Milo have elected a board of Select men! Would you have believed it? Your new sister sends love & wishes you success. Wish you had a piece of Wedding Cake - it was very nice.

Bangor Apr. 16th 1847.

Dear Brother

         I hemmed your kerchief, but had no opportunity to give it to the boys untill after they sent to you, I believe, so it will have to wait till another time.
          The seal I have just finished, It is so pretty I think of keeping it myself instead of giving it to you! At any rate I'll keep till I see you, as it will not 'send' in bundle very well. Some of the letters were blotted out, you know so I did not put them on- if you can make and send them in a letter, I'll finish it. Three at the top are wanting. Recieved a bit of a letter from Mother yesterday by S.W. Furber. She had just heard from Almeda. Lizzie had had the mumps and a run of fever, & then had the chicken pox. Am afraid they have'nt any of them enjoyed their visit very much. Lizzie has been sick so much. Mr. Thaxter's oldest boy, 8 years was taken sick suddenly last night. Had not his senses all night, nor much today. We are all well only Ann, Joseph and I have had colds - have not seen Eliab since Sunday. Ann has a sore throat and I some cough - Jos. got me a bottle of Hunter's balsam.

Great cannon firing and rejoicing over the Vera Cruz victory Wednesday. We have discovered a new kind of drawing pencils at the bookstores, which are very good, but which we don't exactly understand. Can you give us any light? The box containing seven pencils is lettered as follows:
Ingenieurstrifte                                                                                          Kunsblerftifte
_____________                                                                                      _______________
Nro. I.W.                                                                                             1. weich      
"      2. W.W.                      Bleistiftfabirk                                             2. weich u tiefer schwarz
"     3. W.W.W.                 von D. Koch in                                            3. weicher u tiefer schwarz
"     4 M.                            Regensburg.                                             4. mittelweich
"     5 H.                                                                                              5. hart
"     6 H. H.                                                                                         6. harter
"     7 H.H.H.                                                                                       7. such hart.
Zeichnenftifte.                                                                                     Kanzleyftifte
The pencils are all labelled "D. Koch Regensburg" and marked as above according to their numbers. What mean they? We suppose it to be German lingo, but need an interpreter. The pencils are of an excellent quality. fifty cents a box. Angella Dennett & Sarah Treat are both here taking Galvanism. They think it very beneficial, though Mr. Weston's folks think Sarah in Consumption - past recovery. I fear she is. I attend the new church and S.S. with Joseph. Judge - or Dea McDonald is my teacher. I have the pleasure of frequently beholding J. Newton, as he attends that meeting. Looks just as he always did - Don't know me

I guess. Sid. Thaxter is better -doing nicely. Almeida writes that she has engaged a set of gravestones at Worcester. Gilbert pays all but five dollars delivered at Boston. She is coming home as soon as the travelling will admit. Shall we go to Orono May day or not?

        What, oh tell me what, shall I say to Sam Furber? He thinks, & rightly too, I suppose, that he has waited long enough for an answer; but dear me! I have no answer for him, I'm sure. I cannot decide either what is duty, expediency, or inclination! Am I foolish or wrong in being unable to make a decision, when I know comparitively nothing of him. 
        I do earnestly desire you to come here some Sat. and spend the sabbath. Mr. T. is a real good friendly, sort of a man, and would be glad too have you - besides I did'nt see you hardly ant past days and very probably cannot be at home when you go, so do come, won't you?
  Apr. 22nd Ice just gone out. I took tea at Mr. Weston's last night - Ann & Eliab attended great party at Mr. Allen's. I have been waiting for an oppor. to send this with kerchief etc. will give to the boys & let them forward.
                  Good bye in haste Aff. Sister
                                                           Lucy.

Ice did not go - false report

April 26th 1847
Orono

                                          Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf                      Miss L.H. Metcalf
                                                      Orono                                  Bangor
                                                         Maine                               April 16th 22 d 26' 1847

Bangor June 15th 1847

My very dear Brother

                         I sit alone in "our chamber" at Mr. Shepherd's. The clouds still continue to shower down the fertilizing moisture as they have done almost incessantly since yesterday morning. 
           Ann and Lizzy have gone out to tea despite the weather. Mr. & Mrs. T. are reading below stairs so I am at liberty to cogitate all by myself. I was much disappointed at not seeing you again before you went. I sat up till after ten o'clock, thinking you and Jos. would call when you went by, an then was up very early in the morning to see you, but watched and waited in vain till at last I heard the steamboat bell, and gave it up. I would have gone to the Wharf with Ann had I known she was going. Last Teusday, the 8th inst. came Sam in a beautiful four wheeled chaise with crimson damask cushions to escort me to Milo. We had a fine ride. Next morning it sprinkled a little about nine, while the pictur? was being presented, but soon ceased. It remained warm and cloudy until about 5 P.M. after we were all nicely through Pic Nic when the rain poured down. On account of the dampness I did not go out to witness Olive Sargent's performances, but those who did, said she succeeded far beyond their expectations, thought she was considerably embarassed. She looked very pretty indeed, as did her aids. From the field back of Mr. Wyman's where the portrait was presented the procession moved to the hall, ( not into it, as they could'nt near all get in) and listened to an address from Mr. Tash which was very good- very prettily written, but no so well delivered - partly owing, I judged, to

natural deficiency in Oratory and partly to the crowd, and improper finish of the room. He has not voice enough for a speaker, and what he has is not good. Do you reccollect how he used to murder Compositions, reading them, sometimes?

     Well, after the Address, lo! a Pic Nic dinner on the Island. A good long table plentifully supplied with common food, with a row of Maple trees on either side, planted for the occasion. All looked very well, arranged very properly - much better than I had expected. Dennetts, Hills, Greenleafs, Lowreys etc. were there, as was also your Uncle Kesiah! About six hundred in all it was said.
     Daniel Dennett made a long speech - or puff. Quite a number of toasts & Conundrums, some very apropos & pithy. Mr. Tash and sister came to our house to tea, and then went home in the rain leaving his parasol behind. On the whole, a very good time. People generally well pleased I presume. Thurs. A.M. rained hard, about noon cleared away - Sam and I journeyed back to Bangor, beguiling the tediousness of the way by pleasant converse upon subjects befitting the occasion! I stay at Mr. Shepherd's with Ann during my stay in Bangor, the length whereof is not yet fully determined - probably only three or four weeks. She pays my board, (though I mean to get rich & pay some back again) and I go to the school some, and some stay at home and sew. Ann making your shirts - most done - send them right on by Mr. Shepherd in about a week. When I go home, going to take some cloth & make you some more. Mother told me how destitute you were. Poor fellow! wish these could have been done for you to take with you.
  Must tell you while I think of it, Jimmy Newton

and I have renewed our acquaintance. He "sits and sings" at the hall, and so do I sometimes. I judge he is a good-hearted clever fellow. What a deal of rainy weather we have. It rains every other day, regularly, here. Good season for grass I suppose- but Strawberries will be rather tart I fear. The blossoms promise an abundance of fruit. I expect to go home somewhere about the first of July, so I shall get the Strawberries. I feel much better than when you were here. Whether my ride up country is the cause, or the medicine Dr. McRuen gave me or the change of boarding place, or all three combined, I know not. This is a fine place up here; so different from down on Harlow St. Low, damp, foggy (mornings) and dusty there - no good air. Here we get real country breezes. State is a very handsome street, lined with elms on both sides. Besides I do love to live in the Sunshine. The sunshine of the health is not in presence of Mrs. Thaxter nowadays. Her health is very poor - nervous, irritable, etc. Mr. Thaxter is a very estimable man. I did'nt laugh once then where I do five times here.

          Sam brought me the second Vol. of "Washington and his Generals" tother night. Have you read the work yet? It is very indeed interesting. I should admire to read his "Bonaparte ad his Marshalls". 
          Have you ever read it, or travels in Italy? The boys have some idea of getting a Carryall, Saturday before the 4th and taking Ann, Liz. Quimby & I to Milo, leave me there and come back Mon. As the 4th come Sabbath day, Mond. will be celebrated & Ann won't have to keep school. Won't that be nice? I am going home you know, and they all need the ride. Do write good long letters often. Angella Dennett returns to Milo soon as also Mehitable Furber. She is visiting in N.H. now, returns in a week or two. Good bye Affectionately
                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Sister Lucy.

June 26th 1847
Board Coll.
[postmark] BANGOR ME JUN 26                                                             5

                                                                  Mr. Isaac S. Metcalf                         Miss L.H. Metcalf
                                                                            Board Coll.                            Bangor
                                                                                  Brunswick                         June 15 25th 1847

[right-hand side] I am a little afraid the bosoms of shirts are not long enough but hope they are and will fit well. Mean to make you another after I go home and do you want bosoms in them or not- write soon.

Milo Aug. 31st 1847

Dear Brother

  Was rec'd this P.M. the following letter, the seal of which Mother thought proper to break, and which I will transcribe and forward to you, hoping it will reach you before you leae Brunswick.
                                                                                                                                    Northfield Aug. 25th / 47

Dear Cousin

                     I heard at Warwick a few days since that you were desirous to obtain a situation as Assistant in some Engineering party. I have made application to A.F. Edwards Esq. chief Engineer of the Vt. and Mass Rail Road, who resides in this place. I told him you were acquainted with the Theory, and wished an opportunity to learn the practical part. 
                  Mr. E. thought he could give you employment. Will let me know in a few days. If he does, will wish to have you come immediately. The compensation will be $30, a month at first.
           Please inform me if you would like the situation, and I will let you know the result as soon as possible.
           We are all in good health, and wish to be affectionately remembered to all our friends.
                                                                         Truly Yours
                                                                              J.A. Stevens

                                  We at first thought of enclosing the original of the above, but feared you might be gone from Brunswick before it reached there, and in that case lost it entirely, so I have copied it, supposing

it will answer every purpose. If you have not engaged elsewhere, and conclude to go, you will come home first, won't you? Come home and stay a few days at least and get your things all fixed up nice and comfortable. I want you to write soon as you can, whether you got those shirts from Mrs. Stephens, and how you like them. I wish to know whether to make yours here with bosoms, or make the bosoms separate. Also, how many Collars you want made. Give me instructions and I will leave all and attend to fixing your things. I can't bear to think of you not coming home before you go away to stay all winter. I was so much hurried doing that sewing for Jos. and Eliab, while you were here, that it seems as if I didn'nt see you any hardly. I seemed to have an idea all the while that you were going to stay a good while longer.

           Sam was at Milo Saturday and Sunday, came up partly to see Mr. Greenleaf about Mores?. I believe it is pretty much decided that Joseph has him, but must pay his board if he does.
           Martha Hill has visited here today. Blab, blab not a word about "that dollar"! Fred. Loring?, Naomi and Abby called here again.Abby is going on to meet said Fred. at Boston in three or four weeks, to be married. Folks say 'tis quite romantic to elope, but not so pretty to elope alone! Shall I write any more gossip, or leave you now to contemplate the business part of this letter? Guess the latter will be the wiser course, especially as it is pretty late in the evening. Will just say however that Charles has about done haying - that is, has been, for some time past cutting said hay! He has been mowing some Oats too. The corn ripens beautifully - no frost yet.

You will write as soon as you get this won't you? Let us know where you are, where you are going, and what you want done for you. We were expecting a letter from you today. 
Good night

      Affectionately Sister
                       Luy.

  Mr. Curtis from Bangor and Daniel Dennett Jun. debated at the Village Mond. evening last the one against, the other in favor of Slavery. We did none of us go as usual. Great gathering. Dennett pretty much "used up," people said:

Sept 3rd 47
