                                                 Northfield                                                Hampden 
                                                       Mass.                                                     Sept 5th 1848

Hampden Sept. 29th 1848.

Dear Brother Isaac

                             It is a cold, windy rainy day - A real Autumn rain storm. I am all alone - the first time excepting part of a day since a week before I went to Mass. Mehtiable came, you know, before I went away - staid a week after I got back and Mother went home with her, which by the way, was a bad move as it turns out. She heard that Charles was lame & the baby sick, so she was in a quick hurry to get home, but they were both better, and she might have staid and made me a good visit as I expected she would, and then it would have been so nice for her to be here when Anne was fixing away - but we can't help it now. Well after they went home Olive came and spent a week. Then John came & carried her home to get ready to go to Wisconsin, and Anne came and staid most a week after she had closed her school. Almeda has been down too - came & staid two or three days to see Anne & help her. Now Olive has been here more than a week waiting for the man in whose care she goes out. She started this morning. She has a long journey before her, and not a very pleasant season. Am afraid 'twill be stormy a good deal. So you see I have not had a chance to be lonesome since I came home - expect 'twill come upon me now though. You don't know how it seems to think there is no Anne at Bangor for me to go and seem or to come and see me. I miss her about everything - I never did anything without

her hardly. Always went to her for advice about my dress and everything. Seems as if I could'nt go shopping without her! But - she is gone, and I don't know when she'll come back again. She's been a dear good sister to us, has'nt she? You know she has been wanting to go West somewhere for sometime. but she took a sudden start at last. Mr. Pomroy advised her to go, & she thinks she shall enjoy herself. She don't know till she gets to Hartford where she goes - whether west or South. I am afraid she will not find so much pleasure & profit as she hopes. She is always sanguine, you know. You will write to her often won't you? She dearly loves her friends, and we must all write to her a good deal. I hope she won't go far away. Jos. was naughty not to tell you all about it. The schoolhouse has been moved round the other side of the store - only a few rods - and Miss Perry has hired it for a school. Jos. will sell it the first oppor.

          Samuel feels bad about Olive's going away. She is a real good girl - sensible, capapable and kindhearted. Are not those three good things? I am afraid she will get married out there & stay - when she ought to be kept in Maine. I really don't know what to say to you about your health - but it certainly troubles me to have you talk so lightly about it. I am afraid you will see the time when sickness will not be so comfortable as you boast. Do, my brother of you value anything in this world, be careful of your health. Only think of walking & reading with sun in your eyes & wind in your back. Such things seem presumptuous to me. Your attacks are violent, and you don't know what may be the result if they continue. Won't you be advised or at least

entreated bu me, if I am younger than you?

 Have you heard that Mr. Pomroy is going to leave Bangor? Or I don't know that he has decided certainly to leave. He had had an application, and will probably acept the situation of Sec. of the Am. Board, unless Bangorians positively won't let him! Mr. Tappan has left us and gone to Charlestown Mass. We have no minister now -dependent upon students which is sorry times, as you know.
              Your shirts shall be attended to as you desire. Will do my best to have them set well. You will please be informed if you are not already aware of the fact, that wide plaits are just now in fashion, since you have had any bosom made. Hence, probably, the reason you observe buttons, fastenings etc. stay put better on others, than your own shirts, as they undoubtedly do on wide plaits than narrow ones.
          Now, broth', shall I tell you some new all right off in a bunch? Samuel has sold his farm to Daniel Hamlen of stone splitting renown. Eben Greenleaf is going to marry Mary Frost. Naomi Hill is soon to be married to Isaac Lorring, a brother of Abby's husband, who, you reccollect called at our house & vexed us when we were fixing my Herbarium. And, Charles Everett & Angella Dennett have committed matrimony! The circumstances whereof were as follows. Angella was at midnight sabbath before last as usual. Everett never goes, you know - not dressed up, excepting white gloves, which all ladies wear now-adays you know, - after meeting she was seen talking a moment with Parson Jones - then stepped into Mr. Owen's & tarried a few minutes, till Everett came in his every day dress suit with a horse & waggon, carried her to Elder Jones', took her to be his wedded wife & went over to her Father's. Her folks never knew it till the next

Teusday. Was'nt that fine? Well I hope they'll settle down now in the enjoyment of the supremest matrimonial felicity - don't you? Write again soon. You did'nt tell a bit about Aunt Lois. And we have not heard from her. Love to all the folks. good bye Aff. sister Lucy.
Oct. 2nd 1848
Northfield

Tuesday Evening Oct 3 1848

Brother Isaac

                  You will pardon me for not writing you before this. I might give many excuses but as none of them would satisfy me I shall forbear to make them. My business this season affords but little variety the same routine of cares and vexations with close confinement I find to be more fatiguing than physical labor with less care, but I do that which will pay the biggest dollars for then you know are what we are all seeking after
Friday Eve 6th Oct  Guess you will think it takes me a long while to write, since I began we have rec'd a letter sister Ann She is at times very decidedly homesick if she had not so fully actermined upon her course she would even now come back I think, she never felt what it was to go from all friends untill after she left us, I think, however should her health be good that she may received much benefit from her tour. We also rec'd a letter from Olive last Eve from Lowell, she started from there the 4th inst. she goes in company with James Purinson. I hope when these sisters of our get home again they will be better contented to stop with us . And now brother & if you ever wish to enjoy yourself get married as soon as you get ready but do not wait too long to get ready, I shall insist upon being competent to advise you in this matter, I've no doubt but that you really enjoyed your self much now see a great deal of very pleasant and entertaining

company, & were man very fine times, and perhaps really believe that you are pretty considerable happy but believe me when I tell you if ever you get married you will think it one of the strangest things, that you were ever so dreadfully deceived, "There's my views" such as they are Your are wellcome to them provided you pay due regard to them. One other thing, your health, I think your should be more carefull. I've no faith in so much of your cold water at all times and too much exposure although not attended at first, perhaps with many evils is sure, at some time to bring it rewards. 

                                                                                                                       Good Night
                                                                                                                             SW Furber

                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Nov. 7th `848
                                                                                                                                  Nov 6th 1848
                    Brother Isaac
                                      We rec'd your letter a few days since and I must answer it. I also read yours of a later date to Joseph. You appear to be very much excited upon the 

Nov. 7th 7 o'clock P.M. I had written thus far last evening when the boarding house master interrupted me. he came all the way from the Mill here to inform me that some of the men called for bread, when there was plenty on the table and also laughed very immoderately, poor man I threatened to discharge the men made out their bills put them in my pocket and there they will probably stay for the present. I was just upon the point of introducing politics last eve perhaps now all that it will be needful for to say will be that I have this day voted for Taylor & Fillmore. You say that your Reason your Conscience and your sympathy compel you to be an ardent and enthusiastic supporter of Van Buren. I wish you to write that once more before I can believe it. Van Buren who when President avowed his determination to veto any bill for the abolition of slavery on the DC, who sanctioned the Act to allow PMaster to examine all papers and destroy anything they might think injurious to the interests of slaveholders who would if in his power have sent the Aimstead negros into slavery, who is opposed to the protection of our own laborers mechanics and manufacturers against the population of Europe who is in favor of Government's doing all its business with, specid? in short who is now as ever opposed to everything which is considered sound Whig doctrine and is in the fullest sense a Loeo Foeo?

I do not wonder that Joseph should complain of the difficulty of keeping me Free Soilers with such a Leader. I think Whigs show much more wisdom in their folly in the selection of  a canidate than did your folks when they suffered the N. York bamberness to thrust Van Buren upon them. I hope the vote of this day may serve to show you how little fellowship the whigs of N. England have with such men as van Buren and his friends politically I mean. In Bangor the Whigs have gained 300 votes since Sept. which is all the news of the election I can give, I believe it is of but little case for me to write to any one after Lucy has written with a view of telling any news.

           You would not object to advice with regard to the selection of a better half. I suppose it to be of but little use to advise any one when such a subject for most all will go directly opposite to everything that may be said to them. However the most important qualification to be sought from is a power to love if your wife love you it is in your power to make her what you will.                  Good Night

After I am down at the Mill I will try to be better correspondent. Yours S.W. Furber
We rec'd a letter from "Nannie" last night how glad was I - She said she wrote you from Buffalo, and you will probably hear from her at her new abode - (Racine Wisconsin) before you recieve this - good night, sis Lucy
I am so glad she is so pleasantly situated as she appears to be - so much better than I feared - I do hope she will be happy, while she stays - and come back to us again soon.
[left-hand side] Samuel seems to make the same complaint about having nothing to say after I have written that Mother & you boys used to  - but am sure I left Politics for him, and is not that a fruitful subject. ha! ha!

Hampden                                                                                                                                                                    Nov. 15th 1848 Grouts                                                                                                                                                         
Nov. 3d 7th 1848

                                                                                                                                       Hampden Bov. 3rd 1848.

Dear Brother Isaac

                            Yours of the 15th ult. I did receive, though not until some days after it was due, through neglect of bearer, etc.
                       First and foremost, in my letters, permit me to worry about Annie, our dear sister. We rec'd a letter from her at Hartford dated Sept. 27th, and not a word have we heard since. What can be the reason? I cannot think of any evil that can have befallen her except it be sickness, & surely if she were sick, she would get some one to write - but  I can't help worrying. Olive too - we rec'd a letter from her at the same time with Ann, and not a word since. It is hardly time to expect a letter I suppose if she waited till she got to the end of her journey, but she intended to write from Chicago. You inquire whether she has gone? To spend a season with Warren and Theodore - I think it will be very pleasant for her to visit them and certainly it must be so for them to have her stay a while with them. The most I fear is that she will be enticed by some swain or other to take up her abode there - and I think she is too good a girl for that - she deserves to live in New England! You better try to persuade her to come back and be your wife! You ought to have one, and I have no hesitation in recommending her! 
               We rec'd a letter from Warren recently. He seems

[left-hand side]you have heard from them since - Jos. comes down here occasionally- Eliab not often. He is very much confined. Has concluded to leave Brown's this winter I believe - Don't know what he intends to do. Love to all the Uncles, Aunts,  & cousins. Write much & often. Your aff. sister

                                                                                                                                                                            Lucy.

[top upside down] This was left to me to add to & forward. I may as well send it along though & write when I can - this will be a postage full.

desirous of making acquaintance with his new sister. I do not remember him much, do you? He is married you know, and has two children.

        I was not aware previously to the receipt of your letter that you were away from your Northfield home. Should not think it would be pleasant for you. Perhaps I am peculiar in that respect however - somewhat like the Pigs! I love my own place, wherever 'tis, and do not like to leave it. I believe I am not fond of change - certainly not so much so as Anne is.
      Mr. Pomroy has left Bangor for good - preached his farewell discourse a week ago last Sabbath. Samuel & I went up to hear it - House very crowded- many could not get in. Said very little about himself - Mostly advice to the church and Society. I think he rather likes the change than otherwise, though of course would feel bad at parting with his people. - he has been in Bangor a long time you know  - more than 23 years. He stated that he had been with them 12 hundred sabbaths, and averaged two sermons a sabbath without deducting any for sickness or absence form the country. The statements did not include a considerable number of unwritten sermons of which no record remains. 
     I would send you a paper containing the discourse but perhaps you have already seen it. John Adams, brother of your Brunswick minister, you know, has preached for us some sabbaths past. I do like him much, but I think Mr. Tappan has my preference. Messrs. Mason, Goodrich, Titcomb etc. have been here some. Eben Greenleaf & Mary Frost - very queer certainly - but you must not quote scripture so incorrectly "Maid serv't marrieth her master" There is no accounting for taste.

[left-hand side] You positively scare me on Politics, you are so warm. I suppose Samuel & I are a Taylor man! Really I want to be an Abolitionist strong, but I was brought up to perfectly abhor (almost) Van Buren so when the Liberty Party took him I had to turn as bad as Peter Higgins did!

in such matters you know. With regard to Angella & Everett you can answer your queries as well as I probably. I have told you than Angella & I have no concord - I don't know why I don't understand her, nor she me, I suppose. Our tastes, sentiments, feelings, were never in unison I hardly know how to answer all your questions. We expect to move to Bangor in five or six weeks. Do not know here we shall live. Have not decided on a house. Moses & Martha live at the Iron Mountain. He has taken a great contract . I don't know - Sam'l will tell you. Col. Lee lives in the old place yet. Has sold it to old "brother Bumps" of Brownville, who lives there and is to take care of Mr. & Mrs. Lee. I don't know the bargain exactly, but people think the Col. has got "bit." He and Mrs. Lee went to Calais last Summer. Mrs. Lee was quite sick at Bukesport on her return. Some naughty persons  stole all his nice apples & pears during his absence, which did trouble the poor old gentleman much - he being in his dotage, you know, and setting a great store by his nice fruit. 'Tis too bad - Very thievish, ill-disposed persons are harbored in Milo.

        Do you know of Elijah Severance's death? Drowned himself in a small spring or puddle near his house. No cause known. Was recovering from a fever. No previous appearance of insanity - slipped out doors  on a dark rainy night during a few moments absence of his watchers - place so small could only get his head & shoulders in - Immediate search was made soon as he was missed - found him in forty minutes. Dreadful, isnt it? Albina was down week before last. She grows old! How I want to see little Charlie! Don't you? & Mother too, and all the children. Albina says Mother

has been very low-spirited since her return until within a few weeks. She does love Mass. better than Maine, and I do not wonder. She felt very bad too about Anne's going away, but is in better spirits now. You must'nt write about it though, for it troubles her to say any thing about her being sad. I suppose I shall not go to Milo till sleighing, after we have moved from home. Don't know how to wait, hardly, - not that I am not contented here. I am. I have a very happy home,Isaac - and a kind, good husband, always, in every respect All I could wish. I feel more and more every day that I am truly blest in a husband. Every day too, I see that it is no light thing to make choice of a companion for life. If a suitable, good choice, happiness will be the result - if not, more misery than could be found anywhere else, I should think! Consequently my advice to you is get a wife if you can get a good one, & not without; Have I said enough? Guess I have.

            I am making your shirts. Please inform me whether you wear standing collars according to the fashion or not, also if you like wide wristbands, or only narrow bindings, as the fashion is. I judge of the size etc. from Samuel's. Will that be right? I really don't know how to advise you about what to do & where to go after you get through there, only don't go any further off! I'll get Samuel to talk about it. Wish you could come down here to Thanksgiving. I want to see you, I do. Why don't Cousin Maria answer my letters? She said she would. Please to catchise her on the subject when next you see her. Isaac, Lissie Doe is a good girl.  I like her more & better. She is my sister since Annie went away. She has faults - Who has not? I have not seen the boys for some days. Perhaps

Nov. 28th 1848.

Dear Brother Issac

        Your letter Nov. 19th was gladly rec'd last night, as also the intelligence that Jos. is going to Boston Thursday, so I made great haste & good speed & finished your shirts today to send by him. I have not time to do them up & perhaps 'tis just as well, as they would doubtless get tumbled on the way . Just deliver them to your Washerwoman. Sorry I had not time to whiten them. I have not stitched & fiddledidumed  them as I might have done, but made them perfectly plain for loss of time. I hope they will fit & suit you - please let me know. You know folks that keep home always find considerable to do, even with small families, & fixing, getting ready & more etc. makes me somewhat hurried. We have expected all along to move to Bangor the first of Dec. Samuel bought a house for 700.00 day before Thanksgiving, a few roads this side of the Bangor House on the opposite side the St. but sold it again in two days for $50. more than he gave. 'Tis a pretty house outside, two story, white, & convenient inside, but built to sell, he thought - Chambers unfinished. II liked the idea of having an "our house" much, & felt quite disappointed at first when he sold it, but I conclude he knows best. A house in the Jewett block on Third St. is now hired for our use, but appearances & advices of a later date seem to indicate that it is probably best & that we probably shall spend the Winter in Milo; that is, I myself. I will be there, & our husband will be scaling as he was last winter. His Father & Mother want to go to N. Hampshire two or three months, & want Samuel & I to go and take care of Mehitable & John during their absence! You see we can save rent, firewood etc. and be doing up visiting enough to last a long time, all the while! I shall divide myself between

the two homes, you know, if we do so, which however is not certainly decided yet, I did hope Samuel would'nt go in the woods any more, but he feels as losses & expenses have been considerable the past year, if he can earn one or two hundred dollars this winter by being away from home half or two thirds of the time, that he ought to, and I suppose it is best.

    Your friend Mr. Mason is preaching here as a Candidate. We like him much, and I believe he is pretty generally liked by the people. I hope they will settle him - don't believe they'll do better. We've scraped? acquaintance. He called here 'tother night. Is acquainted with Ann & Jos.  you know. I like him. Guess he is a whole man as you tell about - Makes good sermons, too. He inquired all about you. Had the impression that you were intending to study for the ministry. John Adams was considered a lutte too big -aristocratic in his own individual feelings particularly! for Hampden folks, I guess. He preaches good sermons though. I'll send Mr. P's sermon - wish I had something else, good or pretty to send you. Mary P. felt bad about going away, but you know her temperament is such that such feelings will soon wear away. I conclude she & Eliab both got sick of each other - but don't know. She always inquired for him & seemed to thank a good deal of him & like to be in his company, but she is rather impulsive & unsteady. Perhaps will make a smart woman. Some natural defects, however. Prof. Shepherd  is engaged to supply the Central church the coming year. Goodrich is dull & sleepy, very, in his manner, not interesting . Snow I do not know. I am sorry you have such an uncomfortable place at "Grouts" really. Wish I could do anything for your relief. We rec'd a letter from Olive last eve. She has reached the end of her journey safely & pleasantly. Likes where Warren & Theodore are very much better than Illinois. I am really quite fearful she will be persuaded by some swain or other to live there & not come home. I believe down-east girls are in great demand that way. I don't know if I told you before, but when you can spare time I want you to go to Lowell & see cousin Isaac & his nice little wife. I like her very much. She wants to see you dreffully - says she knows she shall like you for your name, & because you are a Metcalf. I like Isaac too very much - better than I expected from what I remembered of him. If you can read this I'll be glad, & write again sometime - good night. Aff. sis Lucy.

Mrs. & Mr. S. W. Furber
Hampden
Nov. 28th 1848
Express
Dec. 6th 1848
Grouts 
[upside down] I'll put in a bunch of Raisins, a Doughnut, and some good gum for you - Believe 'tis the best I can do!

Nov. 28 1848. Brother Isaac Rec'd our "After Election" last eve. am really sorry that you feel so unreconciled to the decree of the people. I shall be engaged at the Mill through next week. We think some of scaling logs this winter, we had an application today to scale for three teams on the Sam Ayers near Lincoln and two teams n Bo. 2 R 10th 50 miles from Milo via Widow Philbrooks. should we conclude to scale we think it best not pay house rent in Bangor but shall leave our better half in Milo while with the other half we "range the wild woods o'er" What do you think of our scaling this winter!

                                                                                              Good night
                                                                                                                   S.W.F.

Milo Jan. 9th 1849.

Dear Brother Isaac

                            When Mother wrote I had not possibly time, but promised to soon, which promise I now fulfill. I am at "Father Furber's" now. Came here day before yesterday to stay five or six weeks (most of the time) with Mehitable while they are gone to N.H. on a visit. They started yesterday morning. The family consists at present of four persons, to wit: John, who goes to school, and is, I expect, a very fine scholar. Alfred Holman, a very eccentric youth, as you well know, but a good steady fellow, who does the chores & waits upon the women. Mehitable and myself, and our husband when he is at home, which will probably be nearly half the time.  He has not been in to the woods since we came from Bangor till yesterday. Began to feel quite uneasy at being so long (three weeks) without employment. I will extract a few lines from a letter he write to Olive last week. "I am quite tired of this way of life. I believe there is something morally wrong in a person's feeling when contented in inactivity. Action, properly directed from a right motive is what makes men. There is nothing so dangerous to the well being of society as the means of obtaining a subsistence without action etc." I have been at Mother's and Almeda's most all the time since we came from Bangor. Mother seems in very good spirits now. She loves little Charlie dearly, and he is a sweet little fellow with red cheeks & bright blue eyes - noisy as any boy can be

and fat as butter, Laughs out loud most all the time. just begins to go along. Charles doats in him - too much I'm afraid. 'Tis very hard work to take care of him. Charles is the same dear good brother as ever. I almost forgot that I am married when I am there, it seems so like my old home. Almeda is about as usual. Lucy & James are good children. They go to school, as does Jane. She is a real capable, smart, child, and with right management may make a fine woman. But alas! that right management! Who is competent? I feel that I am not at all so. I expect have her next summer & shall do as well as I can - I can but think it will be better for her than to remain where she is. There are many bad influences - among them, taunts of children at school concerning her origin etc. She is bright. No one can deny that. Lizzie is a darling little thing. Perhaps petted a little to much that is not strange, but on the whole a very good child. I have written a long letter to Ann today. We have not heard a word from her since the letter she wrote immediately after her arrival at Racine. We feel quite anxious. Expect a letter every mail. I worry a god deal too about you, Isaac, your health. You seem to have a great many sick spells lately. I am afraid you work too hard and have too much care, don't you. Do remember, and feel that life and health must not be trifled with. They are too valuable. Do be careful, and give up work when you are not well. Do you remember my best rocking chair? Large one, cane seat, and back. Jos. and Eliab bought, and sent it to Mother for a Christmas present. Very kind & thoughtful in them & pleased her much. Eliab sent Charles

also ten galls. of the nicest kind (Porto Rico) Molasses (New years) which was divided with Almeda. I do not hear any news from Bangor - do you? I wrote to Lissie Doe. Expect a letter when she answers that. Mrs. L. and Pres. have gone south this winter.  Samuel has got a Scratch! Six dollars. You can hardly imagine what an improvement it is. He is handsome now, if I do say so! There have been three deaths in Milo within as many weeks, Mr. Thompson, old Mr. Dow, & Mr. Verney. Dr. Wilhuis of Brownville died a few weeks since. Left a large family. Mr. Thos. Tash has a son or daughter I misremembered which, People say there is the best school at the Village there has ever been. One Bartlett, a graduate from Waterville teaches. Logan of Atkinson teaches at the Corner. Jamie ? his ear, thumb & fingers one morning. Not very bad, He preaches all the time now at the hall. Very interesting. Excellent sermons. Interesting Bible Class. Baptists have begun to build a meeting house. A good singing school here this winter. Milo has just possessed itself of a Pall cloth. I don't know but some good things may come out of Nazareth even yet! Don't you say anything. It seems to me that Jos. likes Lis Doe pretty well after all, but I can't make him "commit." 'Tis so dark I must stop. Evening , John brought three business letters for Samuel & one for me from Lissie Doe none from Ann. Possibly Charles may get one, however. Please to write much and often this winter. I shall have leisure, and will endeavor to do my part. Love to Uncles, Aunts & Cousins, Good night, Brother.

                                                                                                                                                                                                   Aff. Sister Lucy.

Jan. 15th 1849
Grouts
Milo Main,                                                                                               5
Jan. 12th.

                                                                I.S. Metcalf                                                 Mrs. L.H. Furber
                                                                      Civ. Eng.                                                     Milo
                                                                              Groots                                                  Jan. 9th 12th 1849
                                                                                 Mass.

Lucy                                                                                                                                                                                   Feb. 49
Feb. 9th , 49                                                                                                                                                                        Grouts                                                      

 Milo                                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                                                      Milo, Feb. 6th 1849

Dear Brother Isaac

                                     Yours of - I cannot remember the date, and it is over at Mother's now - was joyfully received last Sat. evening, the 3rd inst. Very much obliged I have been expecting a letter every mail for some time. It was mailed at Grouts, I noted. I understand from Eliab that your station was removed to Northfield again, at which piece of information I did rejoice for your sake. How is it? Was he mistaken? 
                    Josie and Eliab were both here last week. E. spent a week - Jos. came up Sat, and back Monday. Charles and Albina went to Atkinson last week to visit some of her Uncles, but came back without finishing their visit, a Charles Metcalf was quite unwell - teething, which you know usually makes children "cross" to say the least. He is better now. I was over there Friday. Mother has been almost sick of a cold, but is better now. Lissie was quite sick a few days, but is well now I believe. She is a sweet child. Perhaps tis because she belongs to our folks, but it seems to me I never such a lovely little thing - so good, and so sensible too. She has been petted enough to spoil a common child. Samuel went into the woods yesterday. John is at school. Mehitable has gone out to the Village, and Alfred is doing the chores, so I am all alone, enjoying myself. I went over home and staid while the boys were there. Eliab is as gay as ever. Interested

as usual in all the pretty girls. Joseph, judging from his words and actions, seems to be settling down into Bacheloric despair.  I feel as if when we go to live in Bangor and he boards with us, I can make his life happier than it is now, but I don't know. I shall try. He asked me, in reply to something I said one day, if "I considered bliss better than happiness!" I worried to you in my last letter about Anna, but the same day my letter was mailed, we received one from her. She seems to be well situated and enjoy herself finely. I am so glad. I was afraid she would be homesick and sad. Mother feels quite comforted about her.

           Letters from the "Pineries" at Wisconsin bring interesting intelligence. Olive is married~ Her husband (one Joseph Haskell) has resided near Warren Furber some time., & when, four or five years since, he came to Maine to visit his friends, at Warren's request, he came to Milo. He was "then and here" smitten. They had corresponded some time before Olive went there, and were not long, it seems, in "making arrangements" after her arrival. She is a good girl, and deserves what I hope she has found - a good husband. Mehitable says she shall go in the Spring! ha!
                            One Mr. Ricke from the east part of Milo has bought the Crockett lot, which Charles used to own - lives in Almeda's house while he builds his own. Has a wife and five children. Still, good sort of people, Almeda says.  You inquire if it is "Julius Bartlett." His name is Julius. Are you acquainted with him? He was Assistant in Foxcroft Academy last fall. An excellent Teacher, so called. I intend to visit his school

one of these days. You say Cousin Maria has written to me. When? Samuel visited Hampden P.O. frequently though all our letters, with one or two exceptions came to Bangor. He has written to the Hampden P.M. to forward any letters, so if she has wrote since e came from there I shall get it. After waiting a reasonable time, I will write to her again. You inquire what I am reading. Jos. sent me "Allison's History of Europe" the other day, from the Mercantile Library, which I read with much pleasure, or should do so, were it not, like all History, filled with accounts of "wrong and outrage," shedding of innocent blood, and all the horrors of anarchy and war. I read last night till I was faint and sick, and had to put the book away - all about the butchery of all the Paris prisoners, and the execution of Louis.  Well - will you tell me what "house" is on the English throne now. Have'nt I read something about a contemplated, or wished-for alliance, among some of the royal families, which would bring one of the old houses to the throne again. If so, I have forgotten what. Again, you ask how many people will be benefited by our writer's residence in Milo. I don't know Isaac. I don't feel as though I did much good in the world anywhere. Perhaps I am wrong that I do not mingle more in the society. But I don't love to. Besides most everybody that I used to know here has gone away, and their places are filled by those with whom I am unacquainted. I keep close at home from choice, and have no one to good to but Alfred.  I try to help him when he gets puzzled about his sums. We have good Baptist preaching nearly all the time this winter, and quite an interesting Bible Class.

conducted by Col. Lee. We are now on the first part of the third chap. of John - which you know is very interesting.

            I must write to Lissie Doe tonight, so I'll put this by for the present, & let Samuel write some when he comes home, only answering one more question, vis. "What is Samuel's "scratch" of which you speak." As near as I know how to define it, it is a little wig. Whereas he was, in my opinion, good looking before, he is by the same rule, handsome now! I don't know whether 'tis best to hope you will be thrown out of housing, but I want to see you a great deal.
             Feb. 8th I think on the whole I will forward this by tomorrow mail, and let Samuel write next time. But really I don't know whether to direct to Northfield or Grout's. Suppose however, that you will get it before many days in either case. In the last Farmer, I noticed the marriage of one of your Turner friends I suppose, "In Turner, Rev. Horatio Merrill of Columbia, Conn. to Miss Sarah Whitman." Samuel usually leaves home Monday if pleasant weather, & returns Thurs. or Friday. Once in a while stays at home a week. Will probably be at home every other week now untill spring. Does not have to be away over Sabbath at all. Week before last he travelled 140 miles with his horse, 40 miles on foot, and scaled nine hours. 
          We are going to Dover and Foxcroft on a visit one of these days. Principally to Sewall Cochran's. Sam'l boarded there about a year. I mean to go see Mary Tower too if I can. Charles was there a few days agone to a "Grand" S. of T. meeting. There has been a "Union" of the "Daughters" recently formed in Milo. What think of it? Write again soon, please. Aff. Sis
                     Lucy.

[left-hand side] Wish Mother & somebody was here to write another page before I send this- but - guess I'll not wait another week. Love to all.

Feb. 1849
Grouts
Milo Me Feb. 9th                                             5

                                     Mr. I.S. Metcalf
                                                    Northfield Mass

Mrs. L.H. Furber
Milo
Feb. 9th 1849
[bottom of page, upside down] Do you ever get any Foxcroft news now-a-days? Our Village school is going to have a great time at the close. Exhibition etc. Messrs. Tash & Humphreys (the present Preceptor) are coming from Foxcroft.

Milo March 10th 1849

Brother Isaac

   Lucy says won't you write to Isaac,and as you also express a wish to hear from me I comply. But what is there about which I can interesting on. I am the greater part of the time in the woods when I find but little to interest me with very much to annoy and perplex. I believe that it is generally said that every one is apt to think their particular occupation afford less than a fair proportion of the privilages and pleasures of life. It appear to me however that the life of a lumberman actually presents but very few attractions for any one who has the least taste for society or domestic life. Perhaps I am mistaken in thinking that I can in no other way so readily or easily obtain the means necessary to live as custom says we must live. If we could loose ourselves from the obligations (I suppose they must be called) which society has thrown about us, how little apparently of the present labor which we have to perform would be necessary to supply all our wants. But I am far from believing that that would be desirable. I rather believe that an active life, active for some worth purpose. It is the mode of life best suited to the happiness of man in all the relations in which he may be placed. 
How far can we decide our own course in life? We lay plans and build fairy castles and say that we will do this or that thing that we will walk in a broad highway or in some narrow retired path, yet at times how suddenly at time, are all our plans and prospects frustrated. Sickness lays its hand upon us, or death takes some dear friend from our side from whose society

anticipated much to assistance in our way through this "vale of tears." How different the situation of all with but few exceptions from what they might perhaps have good reason to have thought it would have been a few years since. But there is one Foundation on which we may build our hopes of present and eternal happiness which will never be removed, the Rock of Ages, Let us build on that Rock make a wise improvement of our present privilages and be happy to day. He who looks to the future to find the means of happiness will always be miserable. I've enough to make me happy today. S.W. Furber
[upside down] and marry Mary - they used to like each other. He liked her and I know she liked him." I think so far as I can judge, they are a fine family, those Towers. I wrote to Mary last week. You know Rebecca married Edward Treat of Enfield, do you and Lissie has recently become Mrs. Charles Woodbury? The last mentioned board at Mr. Cochran's. Now I will stop - leaving you to make your own conclusions. I wrote to cousin Marie last week, directing to Northfield - will she get it? Her letter directs to Hampden, has been forwarded. I don't know what to think about Joseph. He seems to think he does not get any better. We hope he does. I cannot think but that he will get well of his lameness. But I don't like his taking so much pison, Stricnine, Calomel, Digitalis etc. Mother wrote a good long letter to you not long before wrote last, which, it seems you have not received. I'm sorry. How I wish you could come home while Josie is here, if you are coming this spring. T'would make him so happy.

  I never knew Samuel to have the "blues" really, but it is sorry business living round as we do this winter. I do hope it won't be best for him to scale another winter. Errata. Mr. Bartlett's name is not Julius

Milo Plantation Mar. 10th / 49

Dear Brother Isaac

          It is Sat. eve. Samuel brought me over here this afternoon to spend the night and go to meeting tomorrow. Josie is writing to you at home, so Samuel and I will write some too. Your past letter was received in due season. I waited impatiently for its arrival, as I felt in great haste to write to you, on an important subject. Matrimony against matrimony concluded!! I told you in my last of my contemplated visit to Dover & Foxcroft. We went up one afternoon. I spent the next day there, while Samuel went to St. Albans on business, returned the third day. In the morning I went to see Mrs. Hurd - formerly Mrs. Foss, your recollect. She seemed unhappy - and I presume is so, in her present connection - was very glad to see me, spoke of you with much feeling. Afternoon went to our good Mr. Parker's, - who, people say, is liked better and better in Foxcroft - at night, back to Jewett Cochrans, where we spent the night. Well, preliminaries adjusted, was'nt Mary Tower made to be your wife? I did not see her, as I had hoped to do, as she had not closed her school in the Academy for a number of terms, or rather perhaps, a competetor with Sarah B. Carter for that rank. She is highly esteemed by all. We know she is good, gentle, modest, loving, spirited and just as neat! Do you correspond with her now? Mrs. Parker said "Next time your write to Isaac tell him he ought to come

Bangor, Grouts,Bangor, Goffstom                                                                                                                    Lucy & Samuel
April 2nd 1849                                                                                                                                                Milo
Weare N.H.                                                                                                                                                     March 10th 1849

Milo Apr. 14th 1849.

Dear Brother

                  Josie is writing, so I'll say a "wee bit" to put in with his letter. Our last letter I presume you had not rec'd, when you wrote last, as it was directed to Grout's, came back to Bangor, and was redirected to Goffstown. Had you rec'd it, I doubt not you would have made some reply to mine at least! Jos. is at home here to stay all summer and get well, which we think he has already begun to do. He is a pretty good boy considerin'. How I wish you could have been here a few weeks this spring with him and me. What good time we'd have. He reads and writes a little too much I guess but he begins to go out doors more as the warm weather comes on. Rode horseback up to Boobar brook this morning by way of the Interval. Samuel has got through in the woods, went to Bangor last Monday to find where we are going to live this summer! I expect him home today. We shall probably go to Hampden again however. I do not like to live there very well, but I suppose it is best. Samuel thinks if he does the surveying at the Mill this summer, he can be sure of a chance to survey in Bangor in future, which is what he wants to do. I suppose we shall move from Milo next week, and take Jane with us. She is a very good little girl in the main, (a little too bright sometimes) but is certainly a difficult child to manage & get along with. I think she will make a smart woman, but I feel as if it is a great care and responsibility to take charge of her. I rec'd another letter from Maria a short time since, which I have not got answered, but intend to soon. Guess I must'nt write any more now, but will again soon as we get better, whenever it may be. Write to me then  Aff. Sister Lucy.

[left-hand side] It's nearly three months since we have heard from Ann. Mother, Almeda and I have written since. I think it very strange that if she were sick, some one would have written for her. Possibly a letter has been lost, but we feel quite anxious. Don't you feel glad you have got away from Grout's? That is, if you are not in a worse place now.
[top] Have we told you that "Aunt Polly" has taken a babe six months old for her own? 'Tis one of her sister's Mrs. Philbrook, who died last winter. 'Tis sick, has fits - 'Fraid 'twont live.

Milo                                   10
Me Apr 16  
Lucy

[bottom]My last letter referred to heretofore, was dated Milo March 21m Lucy's last which she speaks of was enclosed in that or my previous one (also unreplied to).  I have forgotten which. My walks are down to the barn, out in the north field in various directions, and occasionally to the old house or up to Almeda's. It would afford me pleasure to received a letter from you. Sam'l D. Thurston & his wife has got a baby. C.W. Rich & his spouse will be very likely to do likewise. J.M.W.

Milo July 5th 1849.
Dear Brother Isaac

                        These Milo people have most miserable ink so I don't know but I shall give up writing. Have got Almeda's, but  'tis very little better. Guess I'll only write a little & finish my letter after I got to Hampden. I deferred writing a few days thinking to write here with Joseph, but shall "back out," I think. Samuel & I came up Tues. afternoon July 3rd. He went back next day. I am to stay long as I please, which will probably be about a fortnight.
  Samuel has helped Mr. Cutts buy the stage line $200. worth and had it in the bargain that I should ride to and from Milo as often as I pleased, free of cost, this summer. So I intend to improve the opportunity.

He won't care for any body, but will study and read just as much as his strength will permit every day.                                                                                                                                                                          Milo July 5th 1849.

Dear Brother Isaac

                         These Milo people have most miserable ink so I don't know but I shall give up writing. Have got Almeda's, but  'tis very little better. Guess I'll only write a little & finish my letter after I got to Hampden. I deferred writing a few days thinking to write here with Joseph, but shall "back out," I think. Samuel & I came up Tues. afternoon July 3rd. He went back next day. I am to stay long as I please, which will probably be about a fortnight.
   Samuel has helped Mr. Cutts buy the stage line $200. worth and had it in the bargain that I should ride to and from Milo as often as I pleased, free of cost, this summer. So I intend to improve the opportunity.
  All things go on here about as usual. Charlie is a lively roguish little fellow, stealing away a good deal of everybody's time but Joseph's. He won't care for any body, but will study and read just as much as his strength will permit every day. He has been worse, owing to unusual and undue fatigue while at Hampden and returning from there, but is better now. Samuel and I are yet boarding at Mr. Crosby's, having capital times, and enjoying ourself very much.  Mr. Crosby has Macauley's History, which I shall commence reading immediately on my return, as he has just furnished it himself. He is a great reader, quite

an intelligent man, and a very strong Abolitionist. I really wish I had your bundle of books. Hope you will be able to leave to come home and bring them before long, won't you? I want you should write to Eliab and try to cure him of his California fever, which he has certainly hot to an alarming degree. What's gold compared with his own comfort & health, and Mother's feelings? I say he must'nt go. He is coming home soon, and I guess Mother will damp his ardor somewhat.

 About Baker's wife, I don't know where she came from - down river somewhere. Is not very educated & is taking lessons in Drawing, Music etc. of Miss McKeen, the lady Principal at Hampden. I have heard of the lady Van Lennep, should like much to read the memoir, though I think with you that most memoirs are not worth reading. Samuel concludes not to build, for several reasons. He would not want to build a poor cheap house, & an expensive one would not sell for the cost. If he should become fixed there, Hathorne might take advantage of it with regard to wages etc. etc. Almeda has come and wants me to help her, so I'll leave now, and write soon after I go to Hampden. Good bye. sis Lucy.

Charles has a lame side. Is supposed to have had a rib fractured by a cows horn, a blow of laterally, not a thrust. He can't now work, which inconveniences him. It would perhaps be proper to say somewhat to you about your bad practice of buying books. It is a

propensity that ought to be restrained. Books are exceeding poor property, as a general thing. A few solid, permanent, standard, ones are exceptions to the rule. If you are to buy books do buy such as Am. Encyclopedia, not such transient trifles as some I might mention, Evangeline, Tennyson's Princess, Kavanaugh, Van Lennep, - not that the last one objectionable, - they are good to amuse an hour doubtless, - their aggregate cost would do much towards purchasing a more expensive work like Am. Enc. of real, substantial, permanent, benefit & value. If one was able to buy books, such for instance, as Vattel, Arnold's Rome, Bancroft's U.S., Upham Philos., also Books of Reference as American Almanac, Best collection of Maps, it would truly be a fine thing. How long would it take me" to learn enough Latin", without any teacher, so that I could make out the meaning of such Latin quotations as I come across in my perusals?

 You have doubtless good right to complain of this ink. We have done our best though at Milo Stores. Of the 2 kinds we have one, though so pale as to be invisible, & so somehow that twont flow scarcely at all - that grows blacker by delay so that I hope you will be able to read a part.
 Answer some questions in your next that may be found in my last. We have got a rather lot of ink which is better yet.
                                                                                                                                           J.M. Metcalf.

W. Goffs
July 13, 1849
Parker's

                            Milo                                           Mr. I.S. Metcalf              5                    Lucy
                           Maine July 9th                            West Goffstown                                    Milo July 9 '49
                                                                                 N. Hamp.

Hampden July 20th 1849.

Dear brother Isaac

                       I acknowledge my fault, and beg your pardon most humbly for so long delaying to answer your letter of June 3rd, and so without further apology begin to write. From the note enclosed in Joseph's last letter you have learned of my recent visit to Milo etc. I returned last Monday the 16th inst. Mr. Cutts drives the stage this summer, and in consideration of money lent him by Samuel, he lets me ride to Milo whenever I please for nothing, so I intend to avail myself of the opportunity frequently. Eliab and Charkes Dennett came to Milo while I was there, & staid three or four days. By some accident the horse run over Charles and bruised him considerably, but he was well enough to come back with Eliab. Also a naughty cow hooked brother Charles, and broke one of his ribs, so he had to give up work a few days, but not long enough for it to get well. It is getting better now. Moreover a little boy down to the boarding house had his leg broken badly last night in five or six places, by a log rolling on him. Has a pretty bad time with it. I can't help feeling anxious every day about Samuel for fear some accident will befall him at the Mill. But I know it is wrong to trouble myself about it - he is in the hands of One who will do all things well. As for Joseph, our poor dear brother Joseph, I don't know what to say. He was getting along fairly, and we all felt quite encouraged about him, before he came to Hampden and while he was here, but we think he exerted himself to much while here, and got too much fatigued going home. He has

had a kind of slow fever since he went home, which left him weak and miserable. The warm weather seems to affect him very much. He is not hear as well nor as when I first came away in the spring, does not walk out in the garden without stopping to rest. He is very patient and in good spirits most of the time. Reads a great deal more, I think, than is good for him, and take a good deal of comfort playing with little Charlie. He says he shall not stay in Milo longer than the first of Sept. Thinks some of going to Waterford but has not decided what to do. I feel somewhat in favor of his going. You know they have been very successful in their treatment of spinal difficultys, and his Paralysis was occasioned by an injury of the spine, you know. I wish if he does go to Waterford, Mother could go to be with and take care of him. It would seem hard for him to go alone.

     Mother seems in better spirits than she did last winter, but her health is not very good. She has not so much strength as she used to have I think taking care of children so much wears upon her, though Charles always seems afraid she will do too much, and Albina is kind & considerate and tries to make everything easy as she can I think.  Mother is very fond of Charlie - he is a dear little fellow - looks just like Charles and a little like his grandfather Kittredge! Is a lively, good natured, thoughtful little fellow, just such as everybody love to play with - has a very pretty eye - full, round and blue. Joseph amuses himself a good deal with him. The little one (nameless as yet) is homely enough. Looks just like the Harts (Mrs. Kittredges' folks)  Is very healthy and very little trouble. We all tried to

get it named while I was there, but could not get all parties suited. Eliab wants it called Tonio, and thinks he has a right to name it, as it was born on his birthday. Joseph would like Ralph or Wilder, but I believe the choice is Rodney, Wilder or Waldo. I think they are all pretty names. I tell Charles no matter which he takes first, he must not use but one at a time, or names will not hold out. I do wish you could leave your business and come home a little while, for your own sake, as well as Joseph and the rest of us. It seems as though you ought on account of your health, to give up your cares and labors for a few days at least in this hot summer weather. I think if Joseph was well, enough, he would go on to see you, but he certainly is not able to go anywhere from home now. I do hope when cool weather comes, he will be better, but I don't know. I think we must all try to encourage him as much as it will do to.

       We (Samuel and I) do have very fine times this summer. His health is as usual, perfect. I have never been in better health, since I can remember. He come from the Mill about half past six usually. Sometimes we ride to Bangor, but usually read sing or talk till bedtime. Do not have so many callers as last summer. We have got a letter of dismission from the Church in Hampden, and intend to write with the Third church in Bangor. Mother had a letter from Aunt Conant while I was at home. She says Baldwin has left cousin Lucy. and is paying his devoirs to another lady. She is thin & poor, but too proud to say anything about it. I fear she is too spunky. Guess I'll leave the other page for Samuel if he wishes to write. Sis Lucy

I won't be so naughty as I was, but write to me soon.

Mr. Tash, as you may have been by the papers, had left Foxcroft & takencharge of an Academy at Calais.  Wm. Baker's wife came from Parsonfield and her name is Morill. all I know about her.
[left-hand side] Samuel thinks he cannot spare time to write today. A German Brig. is loading at the Mill. Belongs in Bremen. I went on board the other day, was treated to "sour 
crout" and beer.
[post mark] BANGOR ME JUL 26                                                          5

                                                                         Mr. I.S. Metcalf
                                                                           New Goffstown
                                                                                N.H.

Lucy Hampden                                                                                                                W.G.
July 20 26 1849                                                                                                                July 29, 1849

                                                                                                                                       Parker's

Milo Sept. 10th 1849.

Very Dear Brother

                 It is monday - which means washing day you know- almost dinner time, but as I think it is high time to send you a letter, I will write a little, and get Samuel to finish it while I am getting ready to go to the Village this afternoon. We came from Bangor last Teusday - a week tomo now. I did not receive you letter in season to answer it before we left, and you know how almost impossible it is to write a letter for the first few days after getting home. The mill stopped a little more than a week ago for lack of lumber to saw, and very glad was I, as just about then the Cholera broke out in Bangor, and I wanted to come to Milo - but Samuel will tell you about that. We intended to have our Daguerreotypes taken before we came away. These - just this minute Samuel spirited water through the trumpet on to me and the paper, so you need'nt think the drops are my tears! Well, when we go back, if nothing happens, we will have them, and as you wish I will send one to you. I am fixing your shirts - putting in new linen - and if you do not come home & wish me to, I will send them. I am making them over so I think they will set well. I do hope you can come home and drive up about having the house finished. It is very much needed, and everything takes as long to move here you know. Your letter was received last week. (to Joseph) was'nt he

wicked to write such a mess to you? What a creature he is! I think - that is, I fear the Water Cure don't do him so much good here as it would away - and it makes it hard for Mother, but she won't hear a word bout his going away anywhere - says she can do all easy enough. There are hardly conveniences enough here. It seems to me he is a little better - at least I hope he is. Really I cannot stop to half write a letter today, but will write more when Josie writes again. "Friends & fortune" I think is a fine story - "Kavenaugh" very pretty style - like "Evangeline", but not much. "Characteristics of Women" I think I should l like, were I learned enough to understand it. We are not versed in Shakespeare! Van Lennep I have not yet read - but it here for Mother, you know. We contemplate taking a ride to Katahdin this week. I do so wish you could go with us. Wish too, you had been at home, when Cos. Charles was here. Everything going on as usual here - Samuel will write you the Bangor news. Bartlett, who taught Village school last winter, commences a high school there this week. Please tell me if you will have the shirts sent, if you do not come home I hope you can come. Don't see as I can stop to write more now. good bye.

                                                                                                                                                                                                 sis Lucy.

Brother Isaac

                   The news you want I suppose. Will first the Cholera appeared in Bangor. Aug. 30th 3 deaths 31st 7 deaths Sept. 1st 4 deaths 2 - 16 deaths 3 - 7 deaths 4th - 10 deaths since then I cannot give a correct report but learn there was but one or two deaths. Friday & Saturday it will

probably leave by the Steamer Kenebec soon, it is thought to have come the by that boat disguised in Tomatoes, cherries, peaches, lobsters and pretended fresh Mackeral most of the cases were among those also who had been sick with the prevailing disease of this season or the extreme filth and destitution found amongst the Sobs of Erin, who have suffered most. I believe there have none of the business men of Bangor died of it. The excitement Sunday and Monday was great, many left Bangor, & disposed to beleive that should the Cholera have cased to rage then it will have a very fine general effect upon the health of the City the streets have been cleaned effectually, and I have no doubt but that cold water has found its way to skins to which before it has seldom been introduced. I suppose there will be no business at the Mill untill ? have a rise of water - of which at present I see no prospect I do not know how long we may stop up here, perhaps two or three weeks. We expect to commence keeping house in Oct. in the house next below Mr. Crosby's shall probably live there through the winter. I may go do some scaling next winter if I find nothing to employ myself to better advantage. Charles Dennett and Mrs. Everett have just called and I must close. Joseph intends writing to you in a few days.

                                                                                             In much haste
                                                                                                         SW Furber

Via Bradford
Sept. 16 1849
Newport NH            Milo                                                    5                             Lucy & Samuel
