                                                              I.S. Metcalf                                         Sep 11, 1849
                                                                Bradford
                                                                  N.H.

Lucy & Sam'l                                                                                                                                                  Oct. 10, 1849
Oct 2d                                                                                                                                                              Parker's
Hampden
1849

                                                                                                                                                                              Hampden Oct. 2d 1849
                    Very dear Brother Isaac
                                           Your good letter of Sept. 16 was received in due season, i.e. just one week before we left Milo, which was last Saturday. I thought to answer it sooner, but literally had neither time nor opportunity. Charlie and Willie, (as they decided to call him) had both been quite unwell ever since they had the measles about the time you were there, with bowel complaint. Charlie got better but baby grew worse and worse until his disease terminated in Dropsy on the brain which caused his death. He ? Friday. The poor little fellow suffered a great deal the last few days of his life. He had one fit which lasted nearly three hours, the day before he died, and Fri. night another which lasted two hours or more, and died immediately after his muscles relaxed. Charles and Albina feel very bad indeed, but it would be a great deal harder for all of us to part with little Charlie. He is a dear little fellow- just such a little rogue as one cannot help loveing. Mr. Kittredge last his youngest child (an infant) about a week before baby died. It has been rather sickly in Milo for a short time past - two or three cases of real Cholera - no deaths. People have been excessively frightened here, and well they might be, for almost every case has proved fatal. The Mayor of Bangor sent to Boston to procure a Physician and nurses, as the Bangor Doctors thought they did not know how to treat i, but the Dr. from Boston

2 lost all his patients, and went back saying he never saw anything equal to Bangor Cholera for malignity. There were a number of very severe cases of Dysentery and Cholera Months before the Cholera broke out, which the doctors said were a near Cholera as the climate would admit, but they have found the climate will admit of it as malignant here as anywhere else. I suppose you have seen some accounts of it from week to week in the papers. There have been some 175 deaths since it broke out, four weeks ago last Thursday This is a great number considering that from 1/3 to 1/2 the inhabitants have left the city. People have actually suffered for help. There have been very earnest appeals in the papers for assistance. In some cases only one nurse could ? when so much is necessary to be done. Its victims have been mostly the Irish and intemperate, though some others have been taken. Mrs. Ingraham, Mrs. Nathaniel Pierce (daughter of Francis Shepherd) Mrs. Dr. Holman, Col. Valentine etc. There have been no cases reported for a day or two. I have this day despatched a letter ten pages to Ann two of which Samuel wrote. Don't you feel afraid she will be sick? I don't know what to say to you for talking to me so much about writing letters! Why in the world don't you lecture Almeda more? I know I am not worse than she. But then I know I deserve it, and will try to do better in future. I've been to Milo this summer three times, once staid a month, once a fortnight, and once with you, which has seemed to break up the whole summer, and, you may laugh, but I have really had a great

deal of sewing to do, besides which I have read considerable. Your trainings for being unable to understand "Characteristics of women" I take patiently, but I do venture to remark in self defence that I have read with avidity and delight all of Shakespeare that I could put my hands on, and vigorously smacked my lips for more! and moreover, when I did peruse said 'characteristics,' I found that I did tolerably well remember such of Shakespeare's characters as I had ever read about. I think some of getting a Vol. or two of Shakespeare from The Mercantile Library in Joseph's name, which he has given me permission to do. "Friends & Fortune" I have read - think it a fine story. "Van Lennep" Mother has not read, and I left it ? Disclosures, I brought back, and intend to read. For some time before we went to Milo, Samuel had made a practice of reading a portion of Upham's mental Philosophy aloud every evening, and making remarks theron, which practice we have resumed since our return. Mine hostess has just been in - she fears I shall write away all my senses so that I shall not know anything by night, that word anything being so emphasized as to convey the insinuation that my knowledge is now very limited, which of course I dare not gainsay. Well Isaac, we did have a grand time at Katahdin. I don't know where I ever enjoyed myself better anywhere. We go there just before noon in a capital road all the way - dined at the tavern, which is a very large house for such a place, and well ordered too, I should judge. After dinner, escorted by Jefferson

4 Lake, who is now agent for the company, we went to see the "Lions." The bellows and other machinery I will not attempt to describe, and will only say of the Furnace that it s a great large place, built of stone cemented together, walls 16 or 18 feet thick, inlaid with fire proof brick, and looked hotter inside than any other place I ever saw except a glass oven. And such a roaring where the wind pipes went in each side! I could not help feeling afraid it would blow up all the time I was there. From the ground, where i the mouth of the furnace we went up two flights of stairs to the top of the furnace. There, when it is sufficiently melted down, which they ascertain by measuring with a rod, they put in ten bushels of charcoal lime stone, dross from the furnace, and another kind of stone somewhat resembling lime stone, which is found near the furnace and will answer in part instead of lime stone which they have to bring from Sebec - small quantities of each of these are used. They use about 12 hundred bu. of charcoal & 15 tons of ore, and make 7 or 8 tons of iron per day. They have seven large kilns for burning coal, which hold 50 cords of wood each, and cost from 700 to 1000 dollars apiece. They are built of brick with large wooden pillars and roof outside. When we had seen all these we went over to Moses Greenleaf's and took tea.  He was quite unwell. They have both been out of health and he out of business all summer. They live in a little house with only one room finished. I suspect they are really poor. Moses will not work, let what will come. They are going out to Ill. in a few

5

weeks - take Abigail two little girls with them, and Augusta Swasey. They think they shall enjoy better health there, and get a living easier. Martha appears just as she used to, only looks poor and careworn. Well at 8 o'clock P.M. we went to Furnace to see them draw or cast the Iron. They do this only in the morning and evening at eight o'clock, so in order to see it, we were obliged to stay all night, which I was not at all sorry we did, as it was really a fine sight. They tapped the furnace and the red hot iron ran out down a trench prepared for it into the moulds which were made in a long bed of sand extending almost the whole length of the building. It did look beautifully - illuminating the whole building, which was quite dark before. The iron ore when brought from the mountain is placed in large beds upon dry wood which is set on fire under it, as it all must be burnt over before being put into the furnace. Some beds are three months in burning, though not usually so long.

            In the morning we rode up to the Ore mountain, about a mile - fine timber road all the way - found some fine specimens of petrified leaves, moss, wood etc. etc. saw the mineral springs and drank of the water. The ground is quite wet all about on the mountain, and on its summit is a beautiful pond were are many trout. We did not go to the top, but the week before, Moses & Martha with Mr. Munsel & wife from Brewer, and some others went up - had a fine time - pic nic etc. caught trout in the pond and baked them for their dinner. They have found no native one yet - get it only from the surface - find it from two to ten feet deep. They are beautiful springs. The water tastes like

6 
ink - almost exactly like some medicine Dr. Mc Ruen prepared for me two years ago. When we came back from the mountain, Col. Cilley from Sebec proposed to give us a sail in an Indian birch - we of course gladly assented. I never was in a birch before - had to sit quite still on some folded blankets on the bottom of the boat. We had a delightful time - across the little pond and the big pond and up the Pleasant river two or three miles, which did bend & wind about so beautifully, forming perfect ox bows, again and again. Fine large old trees on the interval banks, almost meeting over our heads in some place. The birds sung beautifully, it was perfectly still hardly a breath of wind, and we did skim so lightly and swiftly over the water! I did not exactly wish I was a wild Indian, but I did not wonder they loved to "paddle the light canoe" across the dark water. And the Loons how they did holler. We saw three of them at some distance in the water and it sounded as if they were laughing at us just as hard as they could. I never heard one before.

               We came back and dined at the Tavern, rode down to Brownville and took tea at Mr. Sewall's and home. I wish you had gone up there - hope you will next time you come. I am very sorry cousin Charles could not have gone, Before I forget it let me tell you that Warren Furber is Speaker of the House of Representatives at Minnesota, Mr. Crocker who owns the state quarries at Brownville married a rich wife at S.C. and brought her to Ellen Brown's to board. She did not wait upon herself at all, not even make her own bed, and Ellen had to carry up a luncheon of rich cake

(she could eat nothing else) twice a day etc. All this, besides the care of her own family, without help, has brought on derangement again. She is better than she was however. Mary Swasey (Bushport?) as taken deranged at Brownville last winter - has been at Augusta Hospital ever since. Dr. Bates writes that she is nearly well and may come home soon. Mrs. Jenks of Brownville has been partially deramged all summer, Hannah Brown (now Mrs. Rueben Morrell) is not deranged that I know of, but is very mad, so that she doesn't behave decently because she has got a fine boy! What a parcel of news and gossip I have written. One more item and then we'll turn to home. Junius A. Bartlett is teaching high school in Milo & Mehitable  and John Furber attend.

               Now for dear Mother & brother Josie. Mother will not have near so much to do as she did when the little baby was alive - she did have to work quite too hard then - she says she can do all that is necessary to be done for Joseph comfortably, but I do very much fear that our poor dear brother is growing worse. I did not tell him my fears, but it seems to me he loses strength. He says he has more pain in his leg than he has done, and pain in his arm, hand and fingers. This may be a favorable symptom, but I am so afraid that his arm is becoming affected - he says it does not seem so strange to whittle etc. as it did. I do hope you will be able to come home again this fall. Mother feels quite unwilling to have him go to a Water Cure establishment, and so do I. I am afraid they will be rough with him, and he is so weak. Perhaps I am needlessly alarmed, and shall make you feel bad by writing so to you, but I do feel very much afraid he is growing worse instead of better.

8
We hope to go to keeping house in a few weeks, and if so, we hope to have Mother and Joseph come and stay a good long time with us. But we don't know what will be for us. Last summer ( a year ago) we expected to keep house in Bangor and have Joseph and Ann board with us, but instead, we were at Milo, Ann so far away and poor Joseph so lame and hopeless, I dare not anticipate for the future. It has been a solemn time here this fall. We know not what will be on the morrow not what changes are awaiting us. Ann does not seem (judging from her last letter) so happy as she has done. She begins to want to see home and friends again. 

Lissie Doe started for Wisconsin while I was at Milo. She is going to see Ann.
   Joseph has taken up his abode in Mother's little bedroom. Mr. Gilman thinks he can come to work some time this month. I feel in a great hurry to have the house finished, for Mother is so apt to have the Rheumatism in the winter, it will not do for her to sleep in a cold room. Eliab saw Mr. G. and I presume did all he could to hasten the matter. The Mill has not started yet - expect the logs sometime this week. Samuel went to Hermon this forenoon - had gone to Bangor this afternoon to see Fletcher - said he would write some in this letter, but I am sure I don't know what he will find to write! You can't upbraid me about a short letter this time. Have written eight pages to Ann (written closer than these too) and eight to you today - was sick abed all day yesterday - don't you fear I shall be tomorrow? Must dress for tea. They have grand company from New Jersey below. write soon. good bye                      Sis Lucy.

75

Oct 3

I do not know as I have paged this right but tho't it best to be sure to "get out o'the way" what think you I can say after Lucy has written! I went to Bangor this morning to see the Gold Hunter start for California loaded with lumber for Government. $45 per M, and sixty passengers. Mr. Hedge addressed the passengers, what he said was all very well. I never heard him before I missed the earnestness of Prof. Shepperd, he appeared to want to speak pretty. She was detained from sailing by the M.S. Marshall on a protest of a part of the passengers (hired by Government) that their accommodation was not what the Law required on the part of the ? know how the matter will be fixed. There are a number of large vessels  now loading here for San Francisco lumber has gone up in consequence. Mr. Hathorne thinks some of running the Mill through the winter. I hope her may it would afford me employment at home. if the Mill does not run this winter I may do some scaling unless you offer me some greater inducement while up country I went to Dover called on Mrs. Major Woodbury. she had just commenced housekeeping appeared very happy. for your especial benefit I learned that her sister Mary was at home.
         You say to Lucy that we should learn something every day, and you seem to think that for that purpose that books are indespensable. I set a very high value upon good books, but believe that I can learn

human nature much more readily from a careful observation of those who are immediately bro't into contact with us, than from the study of Mrs. Jamesons characteristics of women. perhaps however I am wrong I cannot bring myself to be very much interested in what I know to be fiction. Lucy is calling me to sing with her so I must away.
Thursday Oct. 4th.                                                                                                                                                                                                                     S.W.F.

  I conclude from appearances that Samuel was "put to his trumps" to find something to say, and no wonder. I tell him fiction or not, I suppose Shakespeare's characters are true to nature. Letter from Mother - she says they feel very lonely, would not have believed that baby's being taken, could make them so much so. Almeda has sprained her ?
 We are making preparations to keep house. Mr. Hinman expects to move soon. The biggest woman that ever I saw took tea here last night - said to weigh three hundred pounds.
   I really cannot think of anything more to write today. so good morning.
                                                                                                                              Lucy.

six deaths of Cholera last Thursday - a week ago - one saturday - two tuesday - have not heard since.

   Write if you think you can come home, so that I may have your shirts ready, as I might neglect them for other work of I knew they would not be called for at present. But can do them any time. I really think Jos. ought to be whipped softly for the History of his recovery which he sent you?

Hampden Oct. 30th 1849.

Dear Brother Isaac

                      Your last letter was duly received - For which favor please accept my hearty thanks. Really you hardly give me any credit at all for my last letter. Ten pages too! I am almost discouraged - about trying to write enough or often enough to satisfy you. But let that drop. Our dear brother Joseph, as you doubtless know before this time, has taken the decisive step, and gone to Waterford.
               I do hope it is best for him,  and try to feel so - but it did seem at first, as though I could not have it so, that he had gone without my seeing him once more. We hoped to get to housekeeping before he came, and have him come and stay a number of days with us before he went farther, but he thought it was getting so late in the season, he had better hurry right on, so he only stopped one night in Bangor, & we did not expect him until the next day. The first I knew of it, Charles came down here, and said he had gone in the Boat that morning. I had not the least idea that he would be able to come from Milo in a day, but Charles said he did not seem very tired. Perhaps on the whole, it was easier for hm than to have been longer on the road. Eliab said he seemed better when he got to Waterford than when he started  - was very seasick & thought that did him good. I fear it was only the effort of fatigue and excitement, but perhaps the journey might actually benefit him. I almost felt as if I must go

right home with Charles to stay with Mother a while, and comfort her. How lonely and sad she will feel - Taking care of Joseph has seemed to be her employment all summer, and she will hardly know what to do with herself now.

               I am entirely bent on having her come and stay a good long time with us this winter. I believe all the objection she can, or pretends to raise, is that she must have a new cloak if she comes, and her old one will do another winter there! Burn this so soon as you have read it. We did expect to move last week into the little white cot, next door to Mr. Crosby's - but Mr. Hathorne is very anxious to have Samuel move in where he lives, as he expects to move to Bangor next week, so we concluded to wait a fortnight. WE had much rather live there - a great deal better house - more convenient - pleasanter situation and nearer the mill. I do so hope you can come home this fall - and if you cannot come home, do it possible spare time to come as far as Waterford and see Joseph. I cannot imagine why you should think he had better not go to Water Cure. I thought you were always in favor of it. I feel very anxious indeed to hear from him. Eliab seemed very much pleased that he left him in the care of old Mrs. Purley, who us the Mother of the establishment. I am not acquainted with her, but have often heard her spoken of as a fine woman. Samuel gets Kent's Commentaries for himself, and Shakespeare for me from the Mercantile Library in Joseph's name. Does that please you? I read "King Lear" for the first time the other day. How bad a naughty woman is? Mr. Crosby, as I think I told you,

is a real Hypocondriac. He is very bad indeed some days -groans so you can hear him all over the house. It is very distressing to see any one in such a state. What must it be to endure it? I don't wonder people call it the horrors. Samuel went down one morning, and seeing him sitting by the fire with a very long face, spoke in a cheerful tone, "good morning Mr. Crosby" - "It is'nt me - 'tis Satan," was the reply. His great burden seems to be that he has sinner away the day of grace. Grandma Crosby is very sick indeed - we have thought for some days that she could not live, but she seems more comfortable this morning. How thankful we all ought to be for health - of body and mind. Ans how highly we have been blessed in that respect as a family.  I have thought of it this fall a great deal. Samuel and I too, while there has been so much sickness, and death on every side, we have enjoyed almost perfect health ever since we were married. What a tremendous storm last night - and yet continues. I fear we shall hear sad tidings from the sea. I suppose Eliab had written to you about the fire in Bangor - Strickland's Hock are gone. They are preparing to build again. Pestilence, fire and flood. There has been a great deal of housebrakings & robbery of all kinds since the Cholera in Bangor. There is considerable excitement here about Cooledge nowadays, what do you hear about him and what do you think? - Letter from Cousin Maria and Charles Harmon last week. I have fixed your shirts - they are all ready for you if you come home, or if it is not worth while I can send them. Shall I? Nov. 1st. I though Samuel was going to write

the other page, but he has not a moment to spare, and says he knows of nothing particular to write if he had, so he'll wait till next time. We heard the Bangor  ring for fire last night - do not know what burnt. Abby (Hill) Loring, now dwelling at Milo, during her husband's absence at California recently become the mother of a fine boy. Write soon. Samuel is waiting to take this. good morning sis Lucy.
O.M.V.                                            I.S. Metcalf                  5                                                    Lucy
Nov. 8 1849                                    Oil Mill Village                                                                    Hampden Oct. 1. 49

                                                      N.H.

Lucy                                                                                                                                                                                                                   W.G.
Hampden Dec 16.'49                                                                                                                                                                                          Dec. 18.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Parkers
                                                                                                                                                                     Hampden Dec. 13th 1849

I suppose dear Brother Isaac has been wondering this long time why Lucy did not write perhaps accusing her of forgetfulness & neglect and as Sam'l said to Joseph, I suppose I must plead guilty & throw myself on the mercy of the court - still there are palliating circumstances - we expected to move so soon, I thought I would wait so as to tell you the whole story. We have moved (Three weeks since) and do dwell in our own hired house, - The Mill has "shut down" - The men (paddies) are all discharged - I have made two carpets, hurried & fitted curtains too numerous to mention, prepared a butter firkin full of mince meat (which you must know is no small job) & with the aid of one Mrs. Finnigan picked & dressed 35 chickens (which are packed in snow for winter's use) besides washing & scrubbing with mop & broom, more than I can tell, and arranging thins which you know have been so long scattered in so many places. It is now 1/2 past  nine P.M. and really I have not seen a half hour before since we moved when I thought I could consistently write to you. For a few days have had a lame shoulder & side so I could not well write - better now -wrote to Ann & Josie yesterday & today. We have a very convenient & comfortable house, besides being pretty - wish you could drop in & see us now and then - feel more settled than before since we were married. Jane is here, as happy as anyone

little damsel could be and live I suppose. She is a real good girl, besides being bright as a dollar. I am learning her to write - think I shall not send her to school this winter. I have got her bound, dress, cloak, aprons etc. She is a good help to me just as willing & free to work as busy as I do all day long if I don't attempt to drive, only coax & praise her a little. An excellent girl to obey though. Mother has taught her "unanswering obedience" you know. I expect Mother before long. I intend to lay you and Eliab under contribution for a cloak without saying anything to her first. The question is how to furnish her room. Eliab & I have been talking about it - whether her home-made rag carpet ( which she has fixing) her old looking glass, a homemade lounge & some common chairs, or to buy a pretty common carpet, sofa, cane seat chairs etc. We got two good substantial, pretty carpets this fall for $15 and $13, a real pretty French sofa (round ends) for $32. cane seat chairs 1.50 apiece, good one, mirror for $3. A good sofa could be got for 25 or 28 dolls. only not so handsome. Her table would answer very well with a pretty cover, though out of date no matter- she has also a good rocking chair you know. I don't know whether E. had written you about it or not, but thought I would write a bit. Eliab was down here to Thanksgiving. Wish you and Josie were here too. Rec'd a long good letter from Mary Tower recently, at Woburn Mass. attending school. Roxanna Treat (sister to Joseph) who visited at Mrs. Crosby's last week, said she is engaged to one Mr. Hunting, a Missionary & is preparing herself to go out with him. I suppose it is reliable authority, is it not? Thank you brother for being so frank about the "pretty little girl" you speak of. If she is like Mary Tower, I know I should like her. I think I would dare

to get acquainted with her if I liked her, if indeed you are not already acquainted! You inquire about Mr. Crosby - The cause of his trouble is doubtless dispepsia - hereditary - and also strengthened & continued by the use of tea coffee tobacco, and especially luncheons at all hours of the day during his whole life. I suppose it is impossible, utterly, for him to throw it off as you say, but he is a most miserable being when these spells are on hm - weeps, groans, screams, wrings his hands etc. I never had any idea of such a state before. His poor wife hears all patiently, but is very much overcome by it. Our house has piazza front and back - parlor, sitting room, large bedroom, dining room, store closet & kitchen (very convenient) below, - and fine chambers above having large clothes presses and drawers - we do not furnish parlor nor chamber above it - our room below, "spare lodging room" as Mrs. Cofram says, over sitting room, two back chambers appropriated to Jane, & John Furber, who boards here and attends Hampden Academy - about three miles. We have all furnished to our mind, enjoy ourself much, & feel more settled than before since we were married. don't you wish you could spend an evening with us now and then in our cosie little sitting room? I do. I have not heard from Milo since Jane came - a fortnight since. Angella Everett & Abby Hill Loring have each a son.  Dr. Snow died recently. I do not think of any more news. Prof. Shepperd has been giving is grand sermons lately on Bible characters, Abraham, Judas, Baalim, Peter, Philip, Thomas, Stephen, etc. Have not hear anything so good and original for a long time - speaking of the rage of "Stephen" & enemies when they "quashed on him

with their teeth" - said he "they would have powdered his bones with their very grinders of they could have come at him." He is famous for such expressions. Jane's cheeks are so fat they shut her black eyes almost out of sight. She is very anxious to see  aray. Was talking away to herself yesterday - said she did wish she could find a whole nest of rats with the old one on & she would wring their necks, and set the cat on.  Well I am filling up the sheet with nonsense, & Samuel said he would write some - so I'll bid you good night. Please write soon. I am truly glad for you, in my heart, if your have found your "highly particular star," You know my sentiments & ideas on this point.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Aff. Sis Lucy.

I cam do no better than to commence where I closed. And really I must congratulate you that you think of one in connection with a most interesting subject to every young man, it is a subject which if it claims our attention at all it claims our deepest attention.

        I believe that a man can ever take his right place and exert his right influence in society untill he is married, and I further beleive that he should not marry untill he feels himself in a situation to be able to discharge the new duties and responsibilities  which will devolve upon him. Presto Change I expect to be "at home:" this winter to wait upon my friends, should be most happy to see them all. And how may a man tell all his friends, many who favor us with their friendship do it from a mere love of our fire and table. However it never was my nature to doubt any one's sincerity. I am to apt to beleive all that is told me, and I sometimes think him the happiest man who takes the most charitable view of the world. I think Suspicion cannot take deep root in a warm heart; Are not men's views of the world taken from a consciousness of self? although not aware of it. I will not trouble you with my reflections any further tonight. The subject of news is always exhausted when Lucy has written so I must needs close.
                                                                                                                                                                                             S.W.F.

Hampden Aug. 8th 1850.

Dear Brother Isaac

                                  Your long looked and wished for letter came last night. I have wanted and wanted to write to you, but of course knew not where to direct a letter until after receiving one from you.
                  I am sorry to hear of Alfred's "dejection of spirits" hope he will soon feel better, and do not doubt he will. I was hoping to see him as he went along. He insists that Joseph is better, so John Furber says, who came down in the stage with him. I have had no letter from Milo since you went away, though I have written again and again. If there is the least hope that the dear brother we love so well is any better I should think they might let us know it. They are decidedly naughty about writing. You speak of my getting the girls "trained in" so as to let them keep house while I go to Milo - you don't know how much I want to go to Milo, nor do you know two such girls get along together without a head. Jane is a fly away in the extremest sense of the term, though well disposed and generally wishing to do right. Lucy is also well disposed and good always, but as you know exceedingly slow, puttering and talkative at times. They are considerable help to me, and considerably they try my patience. I get along with them nicely, but could not think of being so unmerciful to 'our husband' as to

leave him alone in their care! You must not let your weighty responsibilities and cares take too deep hold of you - always take suitable time for rest and sleep, and consider your health of more importance to yourself than your services are to any body else. If Henry Dunbarton is sick, I would certainly write to him or to his sister! Comfort and sympathy with the sick and afflicted by all means.

         We have had some very warm weather lately, but no showers or rain for some time - hope there will be soon. Take care of yourself and not get sick with your wettings and fatigue. Lucy thinks of going home next week. I am well and strong as before I was sick, about and can do nicely with Jane's help and Lucy ought to be going to school. Mr. Temple came down here the next morning after you were here, and staid all day. He seems to think a great deal of Lucy, and to feel very much interested in Milo generally. We think some of going to the Seminary to return his call, see the curiosities etc. this afternoon at his especial request. He attends church at the Hall every sabbath forenoon. What an odd fellow he is, but a very good man I think. He seems to think a great deal of Joseph. I love him for that! The old City Hall has been moved back, and is being fitted up for the use of the Third Parish Church, temporarily. Prof. Shepperd is to be our Minister for the present.
  Hannah Moore is engaged to the Hartford Association as a teacher for the west - going very soon. There

was a Circus in Bangor not long since. Prof. Sheppard said he went to see it, and was much pleased with their movements. Explanation  - He looked out the window when they were passing, and was pleased to see them moving out of town!

Little Abby Thaxter came down yesterday to pass the day and night - went home this morning. Samuel is exceedingly busy and full of care at the Mill. Is obliged to be there almost every moment. Eliab has not been down since you were here. You went away and my beautiful "pictur" after all. You wished for a Catalogue of your books - Rhetorical Reader, Evangeline, Hactemus, Samuel, Smellie, two Vols. Upham, Elements of Law, and Old Jolliffes, are all I find besides one or two greek books. Smellie I am going to send to Joseph when Lucy goes. It is said to be very sickly about with dysentery etc. There are none sick in this neighborhood. We eat Cucumbers and all "green fodder" much more than last year. I do hope the Cholera will not come here again, but people seem to expect it. Write to Ann soon as you have time, do - I am going to write to her soon, thought I have received no answer to my last. How glad I am that I went to Milo just when I did - else I should not have seen you at all. I was so disappointed that you could not stay here a little, and yet I was gladder to have you be with Joseph as much as possible. It is too bad for so good a man as Gov. Briggs to be accessory to so naughty an act as executing Prof. Webster or any body else. I don't feel right about it. If Samuel will write

some in this I'll leave it till tomorrow, otherwise it i finished, and I will mail it today. Do write whenever you can squeeze time! Your sister Lucy                                                                                   

                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Sunapee Aug. 1850

[post mark] BANGOR ME AUG 8                                                        5

                                             I.S. Metcalf Civ. Eng.
                                                 Newberry 
                                                                N.H.

[upside down bottom of page] Lucy Hampden Maine

                                                 Aug. 8 1850

Hampden Sept. 11, 1850.

Very dear Brother Isaac

                                      Yours of Aug. 18. was some time since received, and I really intended to answer it before now. Last week Monday Jane and I went to Milo leaving "our liege lord" to take care of himself as he best could - staid till Saturday, when he being too much engaged to come after me, Johnny took the steed, came and escorted me home. I thought I should write to you while there, but the time seemed to be all taken up, and very short at best. Dear Josie kept me botanizing most all the time. He would hardly rest himself, nor let me, till my Herbarium was all finished, filled up, indices made, and all complete. A good job well over and which I was very glad to do, both on my own account and because it pleased hm and gave him something to think of. He does not lie down near so much nor so often as when I was there in June, yet his limbs are evidently much weaker. Why is it? He does not use his left hand at all, and cannot take a tumbler or cup from the table without spilling half its contents. He certainly will be unable to feed himself before a long time if he continues to grow worse. How can we think of it - Poor dear brother - so patient, cheerful, seemingly forgetful of himself. A Bible Agent happened along while I was there, and he brought Mother a beautiful

"Testament and Psalms" bound together -very large print. He had letters from you, Ann, Mr. Dole, and a most excellent one from Mr. Dole's sister (who has been long out of health) while I was there. Mr. Dole has left Exeter and returned home for his health. I have just thought of the reason why I did not answer your letter before I went to Milo. The week previous was Commencement you know. Besides attending a part of the exercises, I had company all the week from Mond. till Sat. night. Mond. afternoon Mehitable and Julia Hartwell came to attend Com. staid till Friday. Thursday Charles Harlow happened in to dinner - about 9 in the evening Eliab and Josiah Ricker came to pass the night - staid to breakfast - Friday and sat. Mrs. Capt. Stevenson (who boarded here in the spring) was here. Then early Monday morning I took the stage to Milo. Have bee very busy since I came back. Mond. washed & churned, yesterday baked cleaned house and went shopping for the Milo folks. Mrs. Thaxter, and Charles Harlow, pest that he is, called. I have not the least doubt he is deranged. He appears more and more like it. I do wish he would keep away -how can I make him? His cold, clammy hand makes me think of "Uriah Heap" in "Copperfield" By the way, when you get the rest of that, do not fail to send it on some how or other. I want to see the end there of. Ann will doubtless come home next month unless something new takes place. I think I wrote you that Hannah Moore had gone to Hartford preparatory to going West as a teacher. At Joseph's request, I bought

and presented to her a very handsome copy of the "Lady of the Lake", with engravings, notes etc. She seemed very much pleased, and left for him a beautiful Vol. of H. Kirke Whites' poems together with a good kind sympathizing farewell note. Her farewell to Bangor, published in the Courier was very good, especially a fine touch for Prof. Shepard - "New England's best Shepherd etc." The Third Parish are about buying a second had Organ - very handsome- great bargain - $800. The Sewing Circle buy it, only the gentlemen are to furnish $500 towards it! Just as much as we poor ladies can do, you see. Col. Lee and wife have gone to Bucksport. I expect they will make us a visit on their return last of this week. I am glad Alfred likes and prospers so well.

 Mr. Wilson who has been City Missionary in Bangor for a year past, is going to divide his time between Milo & Sebec the coming year. I am so glad. Mr. Temple was not thought to be a suitable person, though everybody says a very good one. He exceeded my expectations at Com. Subject "The Preachers' three books." Bible, Creation of Providence, Original, quaint, and rather humorous. Wilson was excused.  I know not why. Brigham and Steele best, Webb seemed to think he should do best, but alack and alas! he forgot his lesson. I had to take out his paper. he felt very bad I guess, and many people were so naughty as to be glad of it - said he needed a thorn. Everybody says he is smart and everybody says he knows it too well. S. and I have written to Josie today. Please to write soon - good night, My love to Antoinette. Your sister Lucy, that loves you.

[left-hand side] Samuel thought of writing, but I guess  won't have time now.

Lucy & Samuel  Hampden Maine
Sept. 11.13 1850
Please to excuse me for not writing before this I have been very much crowded with other things. Eliab I beleive wrote yo you that I would like to get that spare hundred of yours. And if you have any more of them this fall I would like to get them of you as I am having to hire some money to get along with our bills on the ? Senator have got her done is now loaded with dust for Boston I think, quite favorably of her I suppose Lucy has told all the news
Wm. Lowney Esq. of Sebec committed suicide by cutting his throat with a razor about two weeks since, been partially deranged for sometime. Hypo.

                                                                                                                                                                          In haste
                                                                                                                                                                                  S.W. Furber
                                                                                                                                                  Bangor Sept 12.

Samuel has just handed me this to mail saying that I could write if I wished am so busy that I shall not be able to this time have just ready a letter from Ann. She has concluded to come home, will probably be here by the last of October. Good!

                                                                                                                                 Your Brother,
                                                                                                                                         Eliab

Newberry, N.H. Sept. 14, 1850

Hampden Sept. 20th 1850

I.S. Metcalf

               Yours of the 15th inst. was rec'd yesterday enclosing a draft on the Traders Bank of Boston for $100, for which I send you a note Business has seemed to come round in such a way that the Senator comes into my hands as it were almost without any action of my own. If there is any risk in the Senator it is in owing too much of her rather, than in her cost, she is beyond a doubt a good piece of property but I ought to have what I own in her in three or four vessels so that in the event of a loss I should not loose all. I am very  glad that you have been so fortunate in obtaining a good party, how much of our happiness depends upon the character of our associates, Alfred I think well of. his character is in one sense just forming, it seemed now to be in healthy state and if subject to right influences he will make a worthy man. I feel much interest in him. Eliab had been asked if he would accept the Office Grand Scribe of this Division of the S.T. I advised him to consent to be nominated pay $200 per year. We rec'd a letter from Ann a few days since she starts for home about the first of Oct.

[upside down at top] Newberry N.H. Sept. 26, 1850
Lucy is too much engaged today (Saturday) with her baking etc. to write she sends much love and a promise to write next time

                                                                                                                       Yours
                                                                                                                               S.W. Furber

Mr. Crosbt is here this morning, health good.
[bottom of page upside down]
S.W. Furber Hampden Maine
Sept 30th 1850
Enclosed $100.00 Note

Oct 28 1850

Br Isaac

       I suppose that I have been very much to blame for not writing to you before.Lucy washed tow weeks ago to day and I suppose took cold, had a great deal of pain in her back and sides and for a few days had a bad form of dysentery and then a severe cough but would not call herself sick nor allow me to get any one to take care of her Tuesday of last week I sent for Doct. McRuen he said she had the worst form of lung fever and she appeared to be getting better her cough less dry and hard and raised quite easy. Your Mother came down here last Thursday. This morning at six o'clock we were presented with a daughter by Dr. McRuen. Lucy is now  (? o'clock) as comfortable as we could expect and I do feel that she will get well though all anxiety concuming her. I hardly expect the child will live though Dr. McRuen think it quite likely to. I feel that we have much to be thankful for if Lucy recovers. I will write again in a few days. where is Ann? She wrote that she should start for home the 7 inst. Eliab has paid me some money ( 88.28) for you, Joseph continues to fail as I suppose you are aware from your last letters, Excuse this scrabble as we very much confused just now.
                                                                                                                 S.W.F.

I will write a little tho' I hardly feel like it we have had a very trying time 3 days ago & all but dispaired of Lucy's life. I thought we had very little reason to expect that she would ever be well  - if she as spared to us a few days longer; But O, the goodness & Mercy of God She is apparently considerable better her fever has abated her pulse was at a hundred and thirty & O such pain in the side & hard coughing. Tho' an untimely Birth we feel that the Mother & child will both be spar'd. How thankful we ought to feel. I'll take this opportunity to say a few words about Joseph you know I can't do it at home very well. I like to have him see what I write, when I write for him he won't let me say any thing about himself. He sits up more (frequently till after dinner) and seems to feel quite as well or better than when you went away, reads a great deal, hears the childrens lessons, plays Back gammon some, But his limbs are still failing he will probably not be able to feed himself but a short time longer he cannot stand at all, in the least he takes his drink through a little tube chooses it rather than have his tumbler put to his mouth,. How calm & patient & happy he is you already know. I feel better about him than I did his life may be long and happier than most others, even if he never recovers the use of his limbs
They tell of a case of a Man in Hampden who had not the use of his limbs at all for 20 years & is now a well man. God is able to restore Joseph again.
Where can Ann be if she does not come in tomorrow's

Boat I shall feel alarmed about her. What is your conclusion about coming home. I wish you could come if only for a few days. you will want to see Ann & the little niece if it lives.
Tuesday noon. I neglected going to Bangor yesterday, so your letter laid over. Lucy is as comfortable to day as we could hope. The little stranger is promising to day to live.

                                                                                                                                 In haste
                                                                                                                                        S.W.F.

Samuel W.F. Bangor Maine
Oct. 28 1850

 Con.?   Bradford N.H.                                                                                            5/10
                Nov 1                                         I.S. Metcalf

Nov. 4. 1850

Manchester, New Bradford & Old Mill V.

Milo Dec. 30th 1850.

Dear Brother Isaac

                        I hardly know where you are nor where to direct a letter, but we want you to come home. Our dear Joseph is certainly failing failing. He seems better this morning that is, more comfortable and we hope better. Dr. Kimball is here, and thinks him better than last week. Samuel & I came here last Saturday. That morning Joseph had a very distressed turn coughing - or rather could not cough, nor hardly get his breath. The doctor thinks he has not take cold, though in some respects he appears like it. he has not strength to cough, and it is very difficult for him to raise anything from his lungs. The Dr. spoke quite discouragingly about him - said that he might live two or three weeks or a month, and might be taken suddenly without much warning. Joseph has said many times lately "I hope Isaac will come"  - He has not said much about it, but we think he does not expect to live a great while.
          I asked the Dr. what I should write to you this morning. He said his pulse was decidedly better this morning, and he might live till spring. It may be a cold that he will soon get over and be better.
         Do not mention anything about this letter when you come or write, as Joseph does not know it

is written. Do not be alarmed, as he may be better than we fear. I have told you as nearly as I could exactly how he is. in haste.  sister Lucy.
[upside down] Lucy Milo Dec. 20. 1850
